name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament interrupted on Thursday 1 June 2017.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Dear colleagues, unfortunately, once again, we are forced, at the start of a session, to remember innocent victims struck by the madness of terrorism. A capital of the European Union - London - was hit, with many victims from different countries. But murderous terrorism has also struck outside the borders of the European Union. An assault has been given to the Parliament of Tehran and we cannot fail to denounce that horrible attack as well, knowing full well that the strength of freedom and democracy does not yield to the violence of terrorism. We will not change our way of life. We will go forward, as Europeans, to make a decisive contribution to the defeat of terrorism. Having said that, however, I invite you to gather in a minute of silence, to remember the victims of London, but also those of Tehran. (Parliament stands, observes a minute of silence) Dear colleagues, Before opening the session, I would also like to express our concern about the fate of the lawyer Taner Kilic, president of Amnesty International in Turkey, who was arrested by the authorities of that country last Wednesday, along with 22 other lawyers. We call on the Turkish authorities to release Taner Kilic and all other arrested people immediately and to drop all charges against them, if there is no clear evidence of their involvement in the failed July 2016 coup. (Applause) There I would like to remind you that Europe is a community of values ​​and freedoms and that we will always be on the side of all those who fight to defend human rights. Europe is committed to protecting freedom of expression around the world. That is why I also want to express our concern following the arrest this afternoon of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny and many accompanying supporters. Let us not forget the many other cases that are subject to violence and discrimination in the name of the values ​​we share and of which we are tireless supporters.I also want to point out that Loujain al-Hathloul, arrested at Dammam airport in Saudi Arabia, was released without charge.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Sofia Sakorafa, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Union's participation in the Mediterranean Research and Innovation Partnership (PRIMA) jointly undertakenby several Member States (COM (2016) 0662 - C8-0421 / 2016 - 2016/0325 (COD)) (A8-0112 / 2017).

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Rapporteur. - Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is with great pleasure that, after six months of intensive but at the same time creative and collective work of the ITRE Commission negotiating team, in cooperation with the Maltese Presidency and the European Commission, the adoption of the EuroIM Mediterranean Corporate Initiative. This is the first legal partnership under Article 185 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which deals with partnerships between public bodies, focuses on a specific geographical area, that of the Mediterranean, and includes the participation of neighboring countries of the European Union. A total of nineteen countries, eleven Member States, three associated countries and five third countries are jointly participating in Horizon 2020, an initiative with a Community contribution of € 220 million and an equal contribution from participants. With a ten-year implementation horizon, PRIMA aims to promote a fuller integration into the scientific, managerial and economic level of the Mediterranean countries in the fields of agricultural, food and water management systems. More specifically, the general purpose of PRIMA is to implement a joint program for the development and adoption of innovative and integrated solutions to improve the efficiency, safety, protection and sustainability of agri-food systems and water supply and management. of the Mediterranean region. The overall aim is therefore fully in line with the recently adopted United Nations goals and the European Union's forthcoming strategy for sustainable development. The overall objective of PRIMA is to contribute to the sustainable and inclusive economic development of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership, with the specific objective of coordinating, strengthening, enlarging and aligning the current fragmented national research and innovation programs in the field of agri-food systems and water supply and management, as part of a multifactorial, multidimensional and integrated approach. Ladies and gentlemen, we all know that military intervention, armed conflict, political instability, climate change, unsustainable resource management and rapid population growth are the most critical factors contributing to migration. Access to water, food and sanitation services are of the highest political, social and economic importance in the region and are key and interrelated challenges in this area. For this reason, PRIMA is, by definition, one of the rare European Union diplomacy efforts that can also help tackle the forced expatriation of Mediterranean residents. Both personally, as rapporteur, and my fellow shadow rapporteurs, we have tried in extremely suffocating timeframes to help improve a good original text with amendments, which mainly focused on the following issues: PRIMA's exclusive focus on political and non-political respect for fundamental rights, the recognition of the human right to access safe and clean drinking water and basic sanitation. Responding to the demands of the citizens of the region, contributing to the improvement of the efficiency, safety, protection and sustainability of the agri-food systems and the integrated supply and management of water. To support all types of research and innovation activities to promote projects of a wide range of technological readiness and to ensure a proper balance between small and large projects. Enhancing fair and balanced geographical cooperation in the context of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership. To prevent the external participation of external and internal smugglers, by setting specific conditions and sufficient commitments. In strengthening the open character for all countries that want to participate and in ensuring transparent governance, management and implementation. Ladies and gentlemen, opening the debate, I would like to point out that the joint effort between the institutions - the Commission, the Council - and in particular the Maltese Presidency, which has set PRIMA as its first priority in the field of research and innovation, but also of the political groups, has evolved into an excellent atmosphere of cooperation which has made it possible to find the best possible compromises for the timely completion of the process and for that I thank them.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, dear rapporteur Sofia Sakorafa, I am delighted to be in the European Parliament today on the eve of the vote on PRIMA. Our modern concept of Northern and Southern Mediterranean is an artificial distinction. Proximity to this sea creates a shared heritage, and with that comes shared challenges; and science and innovation must be the tools to tackle those challenges. PRIMA is recognisably the greatest achievement to date in Euro-Med collaboration in research and innovation. It is also an excellent example of successful cooperation between the European institutions. This cooperation would not have been possible without the personal commitment of Ms Sakorafa, and the tireless efforts of the Maltese Presidency and the hard work of the negotiation teams are a testament of this cooperation. So I want to seize this opportunity, as Ms Sakorafa just did, to thank the European Parliament, and in particular the rapporteur, Ms Sofia Sakorafa, but also everyone involved in this work and this amazing team that put all the institutions working together. Today, during this debate, we need to keep in mind three things about PRIMA: the what, the why and the how. First, the what. PRIMA will seek to ensure two of people’s most basic needs today: food and water. Why is this an issue for us? It is an issue because it is the biggest issue that we have in front of us as people, as human beings. Without food and water we cannot make it. But if you look at the Mediterranean region, with 180 million people that are considered ‘water-stressed’, this water stress was brought on by changing climate patterns, but also by unsustainable resource management and demographic changes. Water availability, and thus agricultural production, is of strategic importance for the whole Mediterranean Sea. It means the livelihoods of rural and urban populations, and it means territorial development. Water shortages have a negative impact on crop yields, so access also means the health and well-being of the population. We have to acknowledge that these issues are the root causes of migration, both within and beyond borders. How do we solve these issues? I think that part of that answer is exactly PRIMA. These challenges are border blind and are often too big to be addressed by a single country. So no effort can be spared to identify novel approaches to ensure water availability. Right now there is an insufficient level of research and innovation and investment in the region. This means a lack of innovative solutions that are adapted to the Mediterranean region’s geographical needs and that are easily transferable. But we have to put in the means, we have to put in the resources. So PRIMA will fill this critical gap. It will bundle know-how and resources to encourage long-term research and innovation cooperation between the Mediterranean countries, from the North to the South. Ladies and gentlemen, I am personally invested in seeing this unique initiative succeed. I count on you, honourable Members of Parliament, to seize this historic opportunity, and to help shape the future of the Mediterranean basin by adopting the PRIMA initiative in tomorrow’s vote. The Mediterranean region has a shared history. As the great Croatian writer Predrag Matvejević once said, and I quote: ‘Being Mediterranean entails more than history or geography, tradition or memory, birth right or belief. The Mediterranean is a destiny’. Let us then help the Mediterranean countries to take charge of their shared destiny by embracing cooperation and by uniting against their common challenges.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I want to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Sakorafa, for the great job she has done, and also the rest of the shadow rapporteurs, as well as express my gratitude to the Council, which has facilitated the power reach an agreement at first reading. I would like to congratulate the Commission on having presented this proposal for a Decision on the PRIMA partnership for the Mediterranean region, in which several Member States participate. The PRIMA initiative is of great importance, not only because of its scientific and technological interest, but because it can become an essential instrument to try to solve two of the most serious problems in the Mediterranean basin. One is water and the other, as a consequence, food production. We must also highlight the fact that countries from both shores of the Mediterranean are going to participate financially and technologically, and this implies ties of union that go beyond the merely technological. On the other hand, it should not be forgotten that it has a European added value, since it contributes to the fact that many bilateral or unilateral actions that are being carried out in this area are carried out in a joint and coordinated manner. In my opinion, the agreement adopted is ambitious and coherent at the same time, since PRIMA will support research and innovation activities at different levels, guaranteeing the right balance between large projects and small projects. The negotiation with the Council and the Commission has substantially improved the proposal in aspects such as, for example, that the initiative is open to as many countries as possible, but always on an equal footing with the Member States that have already made an effort to participate. financially. It will clearly delineate the northern and southern shores of the Mediterranean, so that there are no eligible countries on both shores. And by Lastly, on the issue of guarantees, it has been very positive that the Commission has accepted to present a statement that clarifies that the guarantees provided by the participating States must be sufficient to cover the funds provided by the European Union, while avoiding that they areexcessive.The object is none other than to encourage participation, so I ask for a vote in favor of this agreement tomorrow.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a high expectation with regard to PRIMA which we absolutely cannot disappoint. This proposal comes after a long time - I thank Commissioner Moedas - but it is a real test. We must show that we are able to reconcile an intuition, a good idea, with the ability to realize the same idea. Why so many expectations? It does not escape anyone that this project is taking place in a strategic area, but also very problematic for the European Union. Expectations because, by placing water resources and their management and effects on food systems at the center of research, this project, this research platform, is concretely expected to contribute to addressing some of the greatest challenges we have in the Mediterranean: that of climate change, that of food security and that of migration. Finally, a great expectation because it is a very significant form of partnership. It can also be emblematic for the future. It puts European countries and non-European countries, in this case African, on the same level, calling them to have equal competences, but also to a very precise assumption of responsibility. I think that this figure, this way of going hand in hand between competences and responsibilities, we will always have to assume, for what are all cooperation actions. Finally, and I conclude, it will be very important, Commissioner, who deals with research and innovation, to show that research can be a concrete tool for improving the quality of life and the environment and for its precise effects on development.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, at a time when the Mediterranean is suffering from poverty and unemployment, at a time when wars and civil wars are turning red on the Asian and African sides of the Mediterranean, at a time when migratory flows are overwhelming. Greece and Italy, the European Union must rise to the occasion and take decisive action to alleviate the peoples of the Mediterranean. In this context, it is necessary to deepen the Euro-Mediterranean cooperation, which, as is well known, was launched in 1995 with the Barcelona Process. In particular, the partnership under discussion in the fields of research and innovation, PRIMA, could under strict terms and conditions contribute to the sustainable development of the region, access to food and water. This requires a focus on agri-food systems and water management. It requires increased resources on the part of the European Union, but they are not available. In addition, countries that support jihadists, such as Turkey, need to be excluded from PRIMA funding. Also, Greece as a contracting country, due to the dire economic situation and the poverty created by the memoranda, must be exempted from the relevant national contributions. Finally, the massive migratory flows affecting Greece and Italy must be stopped. In this context, the European Union must focus on tackling poverty and underdevelopment with a generous investment program in the region and initiatives for the peaceful resolution of problems in the region.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the Euro-Med cooperation process in research and innovation was launched in Barcelona in 2012: that is five years ago. It took us five years to arrive at the day where we are today where we have a programme which, in my opinion, is pretty significant in that area, a programme that should lead to integration of capacities, our capabilities and abilities. We quite often speak of the Euro-Med region as in some respects problematic. Some of us or many of us speak of it as a region which also generates migration. The fact is that this region has socioeconomic challenges that we need to cope with and this is one of the possible replies. I am a little bit concerned that it was quite difficult to negotiate the budget for this programme: it is as if we always have a difference between the ambition and the understanding that we need the means to tackle the issues at the roots, but then when we have a programme which has a solid basis, we have the difficulties to allocate the necessary financial means. But I think that the outcome is a positive one, it is something that we can build on. Yes, it is public-public, but that has a spillover effect as we say that it has to be close to the market. The areas concerned: water management, wastewater, climate change, I mean, we are even talking about issues which concern the circular economy. These, if successful, will have significant implications on the living conditions in that region, in those countries concerned. Everyone participating has something to offer. So thank you Commissioner, Madam rapporteur, thank you for your cooperation, I think this is a good programme to embark on and let us make it a success.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. President, the reality of the difficulties of access to water now calls into question our development model. Worse, some of our environmental commitments promoting the use of biofuels will worsen the restrictions on access to water and lead us to a difficult trade-off between food and energy self-sufficiency. To be clear, therefore, Europe is not immune to a water shortage. As for the southern shores of the Mediterranean, they are caught between a demographic explosion, rampant urbanization and global warming. Almost three quarters of the population of the Arab-Muslim world, especially the Mediterranean, lives with less than 1,000 m3 of water annually, which is the threshold of scarcity. It is therefore obvious that food self-sufficiency is threatened there, since agriculture captures between 60 and 80% of water resources. For Europe, this situation heralds unprecedented waves of migration. At a time when certain states are investing massively in future technologies for the management of water resources, Europe cannot lag behind in global innovation. Within the limits of our financial capacities, the projects supported by the PRIMA initiative must focus on technical solutions that meet the challenge of a sustainable and sufficient supply of water. That is why I will support the participation of the European Union in PRIMA, counting on a rigorous control of the funded projects.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would firstly like to congratulate the rapporteur's work. A program like this is an excellent program. However, it can be further improved in its governance. Firstly, the Commission proposes that the financial contribution be mainly applied to activities of high technological maturity, in the form of a limited number of pilot projects. It is important to go further: encompass diversity of ideas and projects, low and high technology preparation levels, include curiosity-oriented forms of research and practice-based research. Second, under the program, participation in PRIMA is open to any Member State and any country associated with Horizon 2020, as well as to third countries. And very well! However, the selection of projects must be made by a consortium of States that contribute to the PRIMA budget. Only in this way can we guarantee that the strategic priorities of these States are safeguarded. We therefore have an excellent program, Commissioner, Mrs Rapporteur, and with these changes it will be even better. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))).

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I would like to thank you very much for your comments.My question goes in the direction of: How do you think the sustainable development goals, number 6, could affect this new strategy, especially in the area of water, and how could this strategy be strengthened in order to achieve the goals earlier?

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: Answer according to the "blue card" procedure.- Thank you very much for the question.It is, in fact, a clear question and the integrated character of this project, involving not only researchers on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, but also those on the other shore and the specific users of that project - universities, research centers, theglobal consortium for the solution of the problem and awareness of the problem, is the best way to be able to apply the resources we have available.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: - Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the Commissioner and especially also Parliament - and, in particular, its rapporteur - for having made it possible for this initiative to finally see the light after five years of work. An initiative that focuses on progress, stability and prosperity in R&D cooperation, clearly important and innovative, specifically, in water and agri-food, resources that more than 180 million people in the Mediterranean lack, and a source , as has been said here, of new conflicts. An initiative that recognizes the value of science as an instrument for dialogue, exchange and cooperation. And the fact is that the social challenges that southern Europe and the Mediterranean face are due, in large part, to the enormous inequalities, due to the fact that they are the areas with the greatest income gap between them. And it is that scientific diplomacy is necessary and timely to work for peace, development and knowledge. Therefore, my welcome and my congratulations for this great initiative.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. - Mr President, Commissioner, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, I would like, first of all, to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their work, as well as that of the general rapporteur and the Commissioner. PRIMA is an opportunity to deepen the construction of a research and development diplomacy between the two shores of the Mediterranean, which are among the most exposed to the effects of climate change and which should deepen the exchange of experiences and knowledge in the development of mechanisms for optimizing the use of resources as scarce as water and thus also guaranteeing food security. And it is that today water poverty, defined as the condition of not having access to enough water or of adequate quality to satisfy basic personal needs, affects approximately 180 million people in the Mediterranean area. For this reason, this association, which brings together eleven countries of the Union and eight third countries, emerged from the Conference on Research and Innovation held in Barcelona in April 2012, must be established without delay. The debate we have today is the conclusion of Parliament's work on the PRIMA and shows us the interest and urgency of taking this initiative forward. We must remember that in many areas and hydrographic basins the pressure on water resources has only increased both due to the demand of the population and the increase in irrigated areas, putting at risk some local artisan economies, as well as areas of special environmental Protection. Therefore, the development of the PRIMA initiative must have a holistic approach, which addresses both the efficiency of the irrigated areas of crops and urban pipelines as well as the protection of natural areas, wetlands and areas of special protection, always in accordance with European legislation, and especially in compliance with and compliance with the Water Framework Directive.We must, therefore, have a quick procedure so that the entry into operation of the association is as fast as possible.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the current situation of social and political turmoil in the Mediterranean basin leads us to reflect on the great economic and social challenges currently taking place. Armed conflicts, political instability, climate change, unsustainable resource management and rapid population growth are the most critical factors contributing to migration. In this context, I welcome the initiative of the joint PRIMA program, aimed at sustainable and inclusive growth in the framework of the Euro-Mediterranean partnership. The coordination and expansion of national research and innovation programs in the agri-food and water resources management sector represents an indispensable step for a global and integrated approach. Developing common innovative solutions will make water supply and food systems sustainable and more cost-effective. I believe that constant monitoring of the benefits of the partnership is essential in order to evaluate ex post further extensions of immigration prevention policies and to extend the same system to neighboring countries in the context of the European Union's neighborhood policies.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, the sustainable development of the Mediterranean countries, through action on climate, environment, resource efficiency and raw materials, does not depend on the various financial instruments or the establishment of the PRIMA executive structure. The problems of water scarcity, food security, sustainable agriculture and forestry, shipping and the economy are mainly due to the lack of awareness, training and mobility of stakeholders, public and private, but also to the lack of accountability and prosecution of offenders. If we add the effort of private for-profit interests to privatize water, which is a public good, then we are also talking about a lack of humanity, national consciousness and patriotic self-knowledge. The environment must be protected as a national asset and natural goods must be disposed of for the benefit of society as a whole. We do not need the funding of costly European institutions, but cooperation between sovereign nation states.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much to all of you; I think it is fantastic when we come to Parliament and we all agree on one crucial point – that the challenges we have ahead of us have no borders. If you talk about water or if you talk about food, there is just one way that we can do it and that is together and what I saw here today in Parliament was exactly that: we are together thinking about how we can increase our food production in the future for the more than two billion people on planet Earth by 2050. What we talked about today was also how we can have water for everybody. I started my career as a very young civil engineer in precisely this field of water and at that time, in 1993, the drinkable water that we had per person in the world was three times higher than it is today. We have to solve this, we have to create a technology, we have to have the innovation that will change for the better and that is something that we will do together. Ms Pilar Ayuso said it: this project goes beyond technology, it creates ties for the future, it creates bridges and I think, Madam, that you have a point. Ms Toia talked about a project of equals which is, I think, exactly what we want with PRIMA, on this project: a project of equals in between all the countries with the same rights as partners and peers.  Mr Zorrinho and Mr Telička talked about difficulties that we had at the beginning but that we were able to overcome those difficulties to arrive at something that really makes sense. I thank you for that because I think that it took the effort, it took the capacity of us sitting around the table all together, but we arrived at a conclusion that is really better than what we had before. We have here a better proposal and we have here a better solution and that is fantastic for all of us. Mr Gambús talked also about the environmental angle of these problems, which are definitely part of our ability to solve it or not.  So I want to thank everybody – the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteur – who were able to do something really very unique and which represents also for me, personally, one of the really unique moments of these two years and a half: to achieve with you, all together, PRIMA. I wish you the best for tomorrow on the vote and I thank everyone who was here to support this amazing initiative.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Rapporteur. - Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that we are really giving flesh and blood to a rare attempt at European Union science diplomacy, the first public-partnership partnership focusing on the Mediterranean with the European Union's neighbors. PRIMA is perhaps a small ray of light, in my opinion, a small victory. However, I can only emphasize the obvious. The phenomenon of migration, due to the situation in the region, has such dimensions that such initiatives are certainly necessary, but they are a drop in the ocean compared to the size of the problem. It is our duty to support a long-term integrated, coordinated and anthropocentric strategy and a common immigration policy, a policy that will address the root causes of the European Union, of course, in the face of the fearful and ineffective model of a Europe behind , fences and barbed wire. A common policy based on the principles of genuine solidarity and a fair distribution of responsibilities will guarantee respect for human rights and respect for the spirit and letter of international treaties. I therefore call on you to vote in favor of the report because the smooth and rapid completion of our work will allow the Union actions and the conclusion of international agreements with as many countries as necessary to be completed on time. This is how the collective goal is achieved, that is, to put PRIMA into operation, in full operational form from January 1, 2018. Thank you all again.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I think you can congratulate you now, and I would like to note with satisfaction, if possible, the reply of the Commissioner, where he referred by name to the main speakers of the political groups.Thank you very much for this debate.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday 13 June 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – Hailing from Malta, I understand the need to bring together different countries in the Mediterranean region. Where others see a challenging region, I see a region that can offer immense opportunities for people who have many similarities. The PRIMA initiative is not only a tool that can help different countries come together, but equally importantly it focuses on very important aspects of our environment, climate change, our food supplies and the serious implications that these can have.  The Mediterranean region is one of the most vulnerable regions. We already have restricted and fragile natural resources and any changes will have devastating effects on our people. Climate change will inevitably lead to people displacement and this in turn can result in the political destabilisation of regions and countries. PRIMA can be the right tool for both the EU and southern Mediterranean countries which together can pool their resources to develop common solutions for very pertinent issues.  I look forward to a successful initiative with positive impacts for the next 10 years and I would like to congratulate the Maltese Presidency and the Commission for successfully closing the negotiations that are leading to the setting up of this crucial initiative.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: written. –In December 2014 Parliament and the Council endorsed the proposal to establish PRIMA, the Association for Research and Innovation in the Mediterranean Region, and the Commission was asked to draw up an implementation proposal –under Article 185 of the TFEU—, focused on two strategic socio-economic issues for the region: agri-food systems and water management. I believe that this initiative has an added value and an undoubted scientific-technological interest, since it contributes to concretizing existing bilateral actions between countries in sectors such as water and food. Even more evident is the interest from the point of view of "scientific diplomacy" that fosters dialogue, cooperation and conflict prevention, promoting mutual understanding between countries. Since the Barcelona Process in 1995 and the Cairo Declaration in 2007, we have begun an ambitious path of collaboration between both sides of the Mediterranean in which research and innovation are key to creating a common space of peace, social stability and economic prosperity. . Today we reached an agreement on a financial instrument that can achieve these objectives in a concrete way.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - PRIMA is a partnership between member states of the European Union and countries bordering the Mediterranean. The aim of this cooperation is to jointly develop innovative solutions for the water and food supply and thereby make the supply more effective, cheaper and more sustainable. The PRIMA initiatives are coordinated by the EU, while the development of specific measures and their implementation is the task of the program-associated partner countries. In line with the priorities of Horizon 2020, the general and overarching objective of PRIMA is to build research and innovation capacities, and to develop know-how and joint innovative solutions for sustainable agriculture and food systems and integrated water management in the Mediterranean. The Union's participation in PRIMA takes place within the framework of the competences provided for in the TFEU and only includes the (also financial) support of the participating countries in the implementation of the PRIMA objectives. Participating countries will need to work together to better coordinate, align and embed national programs or activities and ultimately develop a common long-term strategic research agenda. In this way, research and development can contribute to solving major problems in the area of ​​nutrition, health and social peace in the countries of the southern Mediterranean region and also counteract mass migration by reducing reasons for fleeing.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Soledad Cabezón Ruiz, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the review of the implementation of Horizon 2020 with a view to its periodic evaluation and the preparation of a proposal for the 9th Framework Program (2016/2147 (INI)) (A8-0209 / 2017).

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: speaker. - Mr President, first of all I want to thank the collaboration, of course also of the Commission, of Commissioner Moedas, but very especially of the shadow rapporteurs for the report. I want to thank the collaborative atmosphere between all the political groups, because the importance of this report requires a consensus, especially with a view to the next Ninth Framework Program. In the first place, it must be known - as you recognize - that Horizon 2020 is the largest publicly funded research program in the world, whose challenge is to respond to the social and economic challenges of society, so its evaluation cannot be further to begin by recognizing your success and your opportunity. A program that was born under the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, especially conditioned by the situation of economic crisis and deindustrialization in Europe, which gave an important role to innovation, the improvement of competitiveness, the strengthening of SMEs. All this from excellence as a priority, which has allowed a leverage effect of one euro out of eleven. However, the rapid and profound changes that European society is facing - such as populism, xenophobia, terrorism, migratory flows, social health and technological challenges, etc. - confer a new paradigm to which we must respond and which we must include. Science must serve to achieve a knowledge society at the service of citizens' interest, a sustainable and inclusive society in which the scientific community and industry are means to achieve the ultimate goal of a science for and by society. In short, to respond to these social challenges. However - and this is the first thing that must be highlighted - it is necessary to reinforce the commitment of all European Union actors to research and innovation. The European Union invested in 2015 an average of 2.03% of its GDP in R&D, with a variation between 0.48% and 3.26%, very far from the 3% that we set in the Europe 2020 Strategy and far from the 4% that some of the most competitive countries in research and technology in the world have already surpassed. These data highlight this disparity and the need - and this is the first call - for Member States and regions to make a greater effort in R&D. Second, an adequate program budget is necessary. We need at least € 120 billion to respond and accommodate all the excellence that has not been accommodated in just the 14% of projects that have received program funding. Excellence, of course, has to remain at the center of evaluation. But we need more excellent centers. A more excellent Europe also needs excellent centers and, therefore, under-represented regions need to achieve greater participation. Also the social and human sciences have to be taken into account and, of course, a better definition of the impact criterion is needed. In order to address the gaps between the regions, in addition to budgets, we have, among other measures, to improve and make synergies a reality. To do this, the role of R&D must be strengthened, but the regulations on State aid must also be reviewed, the regulations of the Structural Funds must be harmonized with the Horizon 2020 itself and the Member States comply with the principle of additionality between money. Social challenges: we continue to defend that Parliament must have a special voice to define and guide them in the next framework program. We need the social and human sciences to be better integrated, as well as to have adequate financial resources. We need the recognition and introduction of research and entrepreneurial capacities from the earliest stages, with a reinforcement of the role of young researchers, a fair return of the public, as well such as greater effort in open science, the separation of defense from the research program and a greater effort on the part of the industry ... - I finish, Mr. President -, greater investment on the part of the industry, involvement in open access and, above all, added value of your projects.And, finally, greater participation in gender issues to achieve the objectives that we have set for ourselves in Horizon 2020 itself.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Once again, I would like to ask you to keep your speech discipline.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am very pleased to have the opportunity to address Parliament today, and I would like to build on the excellent cooperation between our two institutions, and thank you for the continuous and strong support for policy initiatives in research and innovation. Today, what we are discussing here is a crucial report for all of us, and I would like to congratulate Ms Cabezón Ruíz and the shadow rapporteurs for their work on this report. The report includes many recommendations for further improving Horizon 2020, but not only that, for further improving the future and the future programme of research and innovation in the future cycle that we are having and that we will have in 2020. So as you know, we are already addressing a lot of these points, the points raised in the report, but I think that it is exactly because we are raising these that we have to take action, like simplification, or EU added value, or excellence and many more that we will address during the next two years and that will be streamlined through this idea of the European Innovation Council.  This report will be a crucial input for the preparation of that future FP9, and we have been preparing in the Commission our own interim evaluation over the last month, and it has been a long, challenging and exciting process and it is not over yet. So next October we will publish a Communication on the interim evaluation with the political conclusions from all this work. It will also include a reaction to the recommendations of the High-Level Group, chaired by Pascal Lamy, on how to maximise the impact of our next framework programme.  So today, I want to share with you some of the key findings from the interim evaluation reflected in this report. The interim evaluation shows that Horizon 2020 is performing well, is highly relevant for stakeholders and is on track with delivering its objectives. So putting research and innovation in one single programme has produced great results. More than half of the participants in Horizon 2020 are newcomers to the programme and we had a 65% increase in applications per year when we compared it to FP7.  However, this has led to a serious under-funding problem. Today we can only fund one out of four of the many high-quality proposals received. Just before coming here, I did the calculations. What does this mean? It means that more than EUR 60 billion in additional funds would have been needed to fund all these exceptional projects.  I am therefore very heartened by your support for allocating more funding to the EU’s research and innovation. We know that 83% of the funded projects would not have gone ahead without EU funding. This shows that the framework programme is value-added, is EU added value: there is no question about it, because those 83% of projects would not have been a reality if the programme was not there.  The EU supports projects that produce patents of greater commercial value, and research teams that receive EU support grow faster and attract more international researchers than their peers. The programme is also on track to meet its knowledge creation objectives. The excellence of our scientific publication is world-class, and they are cited more than twice the world average.  So based on the interim evaluation, we have learned some really important lessons that I want to share with you. Firstly, it is clear that much more needs to be done in value creation, in supporting market creation innovation in Europe. Secondly, while stronger than FP7, there is room to strengthen the involvement of civil society in Horizon 2020. We have to create and involve end-users, involve citizens to co-design and implement our programme. Thirdly, we need to communicate better, to explain the results better. To show people what we do, and that we support the future of all of us through these projects, in a way that people in the street understand. It is also an area where you can help by spreading information about the results and impact of research and innovation and Horizon 2020 in your constituencies. On 3 July, Pascal Lamy will present a report by his High-Level Group with recommendations on how to maximise the impact of using investments in research and innovation.  Having read the Parliament position, I wanted to share my observations: the complexity, the low-success rate, the decrease in international cooperation and the need for better feed-back to applicants, just to mention a few. These concerns are yours and are mine. We share with you these concerns, we keep a close eye on these issues and envisage the specific measures to address them in the future. Your report also paid special attention to ensuring better synergy between research and innovation in other areas, like Structural Funds in higher education. We have to do more and I count on your support for that. I took note of your concern regarding the balance between research and innovation and I think it is not ‘either or’, it is both. We have to have both. You notice also the issues and differences in rates of participation among different Member States and again, we have to do more with your help.  I am sure that you will find many of our observations in the interim evaluation interesting, and I am ready to continue our dialogue with you. The interim evaluation provides a solid basis for the future. I count on your support. I count on your suggestions. I hope you count on me.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I think we are talking about key issues - research, development, higher education.I am glad that in the gallery we have representatives of the young generation who listen to this - this is largely addressed to you.I greet especially the group of students and youth from Lublin and the regions invited by MP Piotrowski.Congratulations to the MP, congratulations to the participants.Just please do not clap because it is not allowed.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - Mr President! One of the questions raised in the Committee on Budgets on Horizon 2020 was whether there is any added value in the Member States paying the money to the Commission. The Commission sits on this money for a while and thinks about what different programs could possibly be paid for with it, and then the money goes back to the Member States. The natural question that then arises is: is there any extra value with this tour? Or is it just a transactional document that consumes more resources than anything extra? The interesting thing about the Commission's response to that point was that in this way, it is actually creating international research teams, international research programs, and de facto also creating new and better research teams than before. For that reason, we were quite pleased with the Commission's answers to our questions and believe that there is a great future ahead for the following development programs as well.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. - The Horizon 2020 program is so successful because it supports top research and high-quality innovation. I am therefore pleased that the Committee on Regional Development has embraced excellence as the basis for a future framework program. Programs under Cohesion Policy and Horizon 2020 can complement each other. To this end, the synergy between Horizon 2020 and the other programs must be further strengthened. In addition, a good research and innovation strategy for smart specialization must be central: a so-called RIS3 in order to be able to build ecosystems at a regional level. Horizon 2020 is particularly successful, but due to the lack of financial resources many promising projects unfortunately die a silent death. In my advisory report, I therefore argue for a budget of EUR 100 billion for the next program. I would be delighted if the European Parliament even wants to increase that stake to EUR 120 billion. This allows Europe to become a leader in the world of research and science.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! We will already be divorced from Great Britain in the 9th Framework Program. Great Britain, whose best universities and scientists significantly strengthen global, but above all European science, in the 9th Framework Program will only support us on the basis of a third country. This presents us with the challenge of ensuring that science and innovations in other European Union countries can cope with global competition better than ever before. The evaluation of the implementation of Horizon 2020 indicates that three conditions must be met for this. First of all, more funds from the European Union and national budgets. We are therefore calling for an ambitious budget for the post-2020 framework program: as much as EUR 120 billion. But the challenges facing the Union are enormous - these are very dynamic challenges, from the migration crisis to the economic crisis, demography, health, space and climate challenges. We cannot predict many today, but science will have to keep up with them and we must provide it with the tools and resources to do so. We expect that the list of these challenges in the framework program will be verified and continuously adapted to the actual needs. We also call on the Member States to fulfill their commitments of spending 3% of GDP on research and development. Structural funds or grants from framework programs cannot be used to fill holes in national budgets. Second, the new governance of science should serve less bureaucracy and more effects. Grants must remain the most important source of research funding. Loans and other financial instruments are complementary. The portfolio of the new European Innovation Council should help to better support market innovation, to disseminate joint research for science and business, to cover the valley of death, and to strengthen joint ventures that are already clearly successful today. We also need better integration in management and financing science, for example by efficiently combining funds from the next framework program with structural funds, so that no euro spent on research and development is wasted. We can not afford it. New innovative solutions should significantly strengthen Europe's competitiveness, create jobs, but above all support the most innovative industry, and thus the well-being of Europeans. However, we cannot forget about pure science, even if we find its applications only years later. Third, there is a need for new quality for new times. In the resolution, we emphasize the need to open up the framework programs more widely to those countries and regions of the Union that today account for a negligible share of them. If we want to build a real European Research Area, not a paper mock it up, we need to reach the potential of the whole of Europe and ensure that no real scientific talent is wasted. Therefore, the most important funding criterion should remain scientific excellence and integrity, and not the routine and habits of the academic and industrial community. Scientific power can only be built if we risk funding any groundbreaking, unimaginative project, no matter in which country or region, or in which institution it was established.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I am very sorry but this is a 100% time-out and I would like to ask you not to imitate it as I will be ruthless.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I hope he is equally generous to me. Dear Commissioner, you are managing Horizon, which is, I believe, one of the very few positive achievements of the last parliamentary term, alongside the 20-20-20 program for climate change. So, he has in his hands one of the few things I would save from the past five years. Today we all understood that Horizon is an example of success, but we also understood that it has important margins for improvement and we have a duty to cover these margins. We know - now I believe that we have all found a meeting point - that we must act on both directions, which we have sometimes opposed in the past. On the one hand, basic research and excellences - the ten years of the European Research Council have celebrated these excellences a little - and, on the other hand, the whole theme of technological innovation. From this point of view, the European Innovation Council that you are preparing is very important. It would be important that Parliament too could participate in all the working and reflection groups, which are working towards this goal, and the participation of SMEs, industry and the industrial sector is important, although it has not increased its shares. of research. Here is a great problem of resources that we will try to solve with you. As a final suggestion - my colleague Cabezón told him about the contents - I would like to refer to the topic of health. There are research, hospitalization and treatment institutes of the highest level in Europe and a network must be created. You should give this input, Commissioner, in order to draw from there the fruits of research which has an immediate impact on people's health.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I am so sorry, but I am asking for time discipline.We have to finish this debate before midnight, so I will turn off the microphone, I will be using this privilege.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - I am pleased that we are voting on this important report tomorrow. Research and innovation are essential for the prosperity of the European Union. It is therefore not surprising that Horizon 2020 is such a great success. The European Union shows that action in the field of research and innovation has clear added value. Unfortunately, the program is also a victim of its own success. We see that the success rate has plummeted due to over-registration. We are currently around 10%, which means that a number of very brilliant researchers are dropping out and not taking their chances. This in turn threatens us to miss crucial opportunities. That is why I would like to argue for more budget for the next framework program and for a stricter selection procedure in the two-step procedure. We have long debated the role of companies in the framework program. These companies are essential for a successful program: there the added value is created, there the research results are converted into economic added value. I therefore believe that we should review the rules of participation for the next Framework Program, with the aim of involving even more companies. Finally, I would like to say that I think the report puts the right emphasis on what is going well and badly in the program and has a correct vision for the next framework program. We must continue to focus on the problems that concern citizens: a good job, health and safety. I am therefore pleased to see that the minds are ripe to invest in defense research.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Continuing to invest in research and development is the only way to remain relevant as a society. It is therefore very important that we clearly state that Horizon 2020 is an enormous added value for the European Union and the Member States. Not only by freeing up additional resources, but above all by focusing on cross-border cooperation. These cross-pollinations are considered very important by all participants and, together with the excellence criterion, form the core of this program. If we then look at Framework Program 9, these are the elements that must absolutely be preserved. I have always opposed this research program being treated as a kind of cohesion fund. We must recognize that there is a problem with the EU-13 uptake of funds, but those Member States must invest in good training and infrastructure. This is of course a precondition for being able to conduct excellent research and obtain European funds. That is why I also think it is important that we look at further deepening synergies with the Structural Funds. There is already an R & amp; D aspect to this, but that could be further developed to close the gap between the EU-13 and the EU-15. Industry participation is also very important. This fund should not only finance basic research or solve scientific issues. We also need to give it concrete applications and bring them to the market. This balance is very important. We have to deal with this in a balanced way and divide the focus sufficiently between the high and low TRL scales. We must also recognize that industry plays a vital role in the realization and implementation of innovation. It often also benefits SMEs, which thrive under the wings of these large companies. With our report, we are sending a good and clear signal to the Commission and the Member States about how we see Framework Program 9 and where we are research policy should go.I am already looking forward to further exciting discussions on this.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for the document she is presenting to us. It is true that we all agree with the importance of the report that is presented and the way it talks about Horizon 2020, but there is a big difference between thinking that it is important and believing that it is really important. There are many important things that have happened in the last few years and I believe that from the good news of the European Union, Horizon 2020 is probably the best. There aren't that many more that we can hold on to. However, where there were cuts, it was also in Horizon 2020. Therefore, it is important to reinforce investment. What we have seen in recent years cannot happen. Is that every time you need money for something, whatever it is, where do you get it? Horizon 2020. We come here to the plenary and say that it is very important to invest in research; next, we need money for something else and what do we say? Let's get money for the investigation. It can not be. To articulate research and innovation, we really need to have public and quality investment. There is no other option. Likewise, we cannot sacrifice research, because we will never seriously innovate if we kill basic research, quality research, and therefore we must continue to bet. We cannot treat researchers badly, we have to give them work with rights: to those who have been working for a long time, and to young researchers who need a guarantee of the future. We need to have more equality between men and women and we need to invest more in small and medium-sized businesses. A lot has gone well, but there is still a long way to go and I sincerely hope that investment, being public, will increase in the next Framework Program and that Horizon 2020 will not be fetched every time it is needed, whether for What it will be.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, the Horizon 2020 program is essential for Europe. Its almost one hundred billion euros allow to promote research and innovation for researchers, companies, technology centers and public entities throughout the continent. And to make this program even more efficient and fair, we need to continue to strengthen the role of women. Because today women still have obstacles to a scientific career. Some less visible, such as gender biases, which condition young women to choose their career. And others that are more visible, such as the wage gap or family care, which are mainly carried out by women. That is why it is so important to approve the Directive on maternity leave, which was adopted in 2010 and which the European Commission has withdrawn. When we speak of women and science, we also speak of inequality. Undoubtedly, Marie Curie could have accomplished much more if she had had, in her time, the support of French institutions. It is true that the Commission has taken positive steps, with good results. However, the target of 50% participation by women has only been exceeded in advisory groups. Their participation among project coordinators and in evaluation panels remains below the objectives, as does the gender dimension in the research contents. Therefore, we ask the Commission to be more ambitious and to maintain independent funding for gender equality initiatives in research and innovation and for structural change projects on gender. Financing these lines is quite simple. Let's stop spending more and more money on defense and military spending and use it on projects that are committed to equality and efficiency. This is how a better and fairer society and a continent at peace are built.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for all his hard work and good balance between fundamental research, applied research and innovation, innovation and innovation – let me underline this word three times! Key global economic challenges lie in front of us and EU framework programmes are the tools to achieving our goals and to overcome the challenges. My first point: I welcome recommendations to strengthen Horizon 2020, and with the budget of EUR 120 billion because this is not expenditure; it is, as a matter of fact, an investment in our good future. Point number two: we have, of course, got the most important goal – to continue building our excellence within the European Research Area. On the other hand, we must address performance gaps and bring the low-performing regions back on track if we want to win. On the basis of the ambitious design of FP9 we should try to eliminate those gaps completely. A small remark may be detailed at the end: very important – research on defence industry, which could be something like a leverage in many other fields, I would like to thank Ms Cabezón Ruiz for incorporating my amendment on this topic into the text.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by emphasizing the rapporteur's excellent work, the reflection it has provided. Horizon 2020 is a key program to give a global voice to the European Union and the research process, when open and strong, values ​​the whole society in a transversal way, mobilizes the best available resources and allows people and teams to be attracted to our territory high quality. It is, therefore, necessary to safeguard the financial base of the program, the one hundred and twenty billion for the Framework Program, and apply them according to the basic principles of excellence, openness and impact on the situation of companies, including SMEs, in employment and the quality of life of citizens. It is also necessary to communicate, increasingly better, what we have achieved and what we do for people's daily lives. I would also like to emphasize and congratulate the Commissioner on his excellent work and refer, as he has argued, that excellence must be crossed with the openness and concrete impact of the projects. It must incorporate ambition, risk-taking, the ability to open new avenues for the affirmation of European science, knowledge and technology.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!Madam Rapporteur!Commissioner!Thank you very much for good work and solid work.I think that a consensus is being built in this House on the need to increase the budget for Horizon 2020, to integrate it with other EU policies and, finally, with the most important one, that is, achieving a higher than ever rate of success.I would like to highlight one element absent from this debate, namely the need to include cities in the implementation of the program.More cities than regions, in my opinion.Cities are places where universities, research institutions and big companies operate.They are places of particular interest for development and innovation and I think the Commission should rethink the much more intensive participation of cities as partners in this program.This is my recommendation.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, quite a few years back, together with Esko Aho and two other colleagues, we were evaluating the framework programme and I must say that it was quite depressing. In fact, from the interviews with the applicants, successful and unsuccessful, those that did not apply and the Commission, we found out that the best outcome was not working. In comparison with that, Horizon 2020 is a success for sure. But I think there are three lines on which we can still improve. First, as many colleagues have said, we definitely need to recover the budget, so that is something where Parliament can deliver impetus. Second, we can still do better in terms of simplifying and lowering the administrative burden. This still plays a significant role in terms of, let us say, applicants avoiding it. And third, which is absolutely key, I think we should still fine-tune the tools of evaluation. For me, the question is how much did it lead to real innovation? How many projects led to commercialisation, and so on, and in a longer time span? Let us work on that.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the Commissioner. I think it is important to understand that in the global world and the global economy, there is no such thing as ‘almost innovating’ and there is no real idea of being ‘number two’ because that always means that you are losing. In the globalised economy, if Europe wants to be in the lead, we must ensure that the Framework Programme is facilitating leadership regarding the knowledge economy, research and science. Three things are crucial: first of all, we need to have excellence at the centre of all our work, because otherwise we will not use the opportunity of the framework programmes. Excellence is the only way to achieve leadership and to ensure that we are not ‘number two’ or ‘number three’. Second, we need to ensure that we are at the centre of global research and science, meaning that we shall be open and attracting research and science and investments from all over the world. Third, and importantly, we need to raise our ambitions, we need to double our spending on research and science if we want things to come true, all the hopes and promises we have.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! I would like to make three points regarding the Horizon 2020 program. First case. The huge territorial disproportion of the program beneficiaries needs to be explained. I hope that in the assessment announced by the Commissioner, which is to be published in October, we will learn, inter alia, attempts to answer the question why the intellectual potential of all Member States is not used as evenly as possible. Second case. You also told us that only some projects, due to budget constraints, can be financed, but this does not mean that good projects are to disappear. That is why I propose to extend the projects awarded with the Seal of Excellence to research proposals with an excellent science base. This will allow these projects to obtain financing from other sources. Third case. Many of the speakers mentioned the need to increase synergies between Horizon 2020 and structural or investment programs, but this requires much greater involvement of national contact points and representatives of the European Investment Bank. One last point. Thank you, Commissioner, for noticing the need for cooperation and correlation between the European Research Area and the European Higher Education Area.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, high levels of know-how, science and research are a prerequisite for Europe's future success. It is important that, even in times of economic hardship, sufficient investment is made in research and science. It is worrying that, at present, only a few European Union Member States - Finland, Sweden, Denmark and Austria - spend more than 3% of their GDP on research and development, as the target has been set. It is important that all Member States are encouraged to take this path. Horizon 2020 is the most important program for us at European level to promote research and innovation. We know that the most important thing now is to ensure that we continue to have sufficient resources for the program, and I warmly recommend that we increase funding for the program. It will continue to be essential that scientific excellence and basic research be considered a key objective in that program. Emphasis must also be placed on the grant-based system, as only it is suitable for funding basic research. Efforts must continue to be made to streamline administration so that processes run as smoothly as possible for researchers.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleague on this excellent report. It underlines that this Parliament is a champion of Horizon 2020, the largest research area in the world. The programme delivers on the priorities of people across the EU, stimulating jobs and growth, not just now but long into the future. It is also a shining example of how the EU brings added value to all citizens, far beyond those directly involved. It is through this programme we can diagnose, treat and cure illnesses and diseases or find affordable, sustainable ways of meeting our energy needs. We must recognise the success of Horizon 2020 and realise it demonstrates the need to allocate more resources to this excellence-based research long into the future to protect and strengthen its achievements. Finally, when we do something well we should learn from it, build on it and, vitally, as the Commissioner said, tell people about it!

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!What are the reports evaluating this time that is running out for?First of all, to make the next perspective, in short, to be better, without gaps, without flaws, to run more efficiently.I think that my colleagues in the debate have completed this report.Barbara Kudrycka spoke about the need to increase funding and improve the relevance of grants.Jerzy Buzek said, among other things, that it is necessary to strengthen defense, this defense and this security, which depend on the progress of science.There is a need to strengthen industries and technologies that are related to space.It suits me very well, I will not argue with some individual diagnoses, but in the end I want to say that it is very important that this next perspective is more flexible, because then we will respond more efficiently to events that occur at a certain time.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the rapid and drastic changes that Europe is facing, from migratory flows to new energy and environmental challenges, also require research programs to be updated and strengthened in some way. Horizon 2020 is the world's leading research program, with all that this entails in terms of implementation complexity, strategic relevance of objectives and the need for political attention. It is essential to invest more and more budgetary resources, just as it is necessary to promote forms of synergy with other European programs and other sources of financing and continue to give priority to innovation in the industrial fabric. This report is in fact a stimulus for the Commission in view of the mid-term review of Horizon 2020. In addition to the adjustments that need to be made to meet the new challenges, it is necessary to strengthen the structure and foundations of the program and to aim for more transparent implementation. , clear and simplified, to less fragmentation, as well as ex post monitoring and measurement of the impact of public funding.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, Horizon 2020 is an important initiative that to some extent allows the European Union to meet economic and social challenges. Horizon 2020 was affected by the economic crisis, violent deindustrialisation and unemployment. For this reason, the program attaches great importance to innovation, as a tool for improving the competitiveness of the European Union. Of course, it took several years for the European Union to realize that the competitiveness of the European economy must be based on research, education, training, innovation, excellence, and not on the "Chineseization" of wages imposed by the "Euro +" in March 2010. Therefore, it is necessary to increase investment in research and development and reach 5% of the Union's GDP. In this context, universities and research institutes must play an important role. The same goes for technology parks, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises. In addition, large companies have to invest their own funds in research and innovation and not just wait to receive money from European funds.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, Horizon 2020 has many weaknesses that need to be addressed. As it turns out, access to finance, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, is very difficult. The synergies between the academic community and the private sector, which are favored by the program, often turn research into a tool of large multinationals, which is developed based on their own interests. We consider the new proposal, which is being promoted to create a special budget, to finance research in the military sector, to be particularly dangerous. We demand that criticism be leveled at the fact that today, through the program, human rights activists are being funded, for example, Israeli actors in the occupied Palestinian territories. We will not accept the use of the program for the militarization of the Union. What is needed is to promote substantial reforms in the program, based on the needs of society, to support the real economy, to contribute to social development and to lead to the creation of new quality jobs through these programs.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - It has been made clear on several occasions that Horizon 2020 is important for ensuring the competitiveness of European industry, it must promote excellence, basic research and applied research.We all agree with this as well as with the increase in resources.I would like to point out two things that I consider essential.It is not possible for the disproportion between the drawing of Western and Eastern countries to continue.84% to 4.5% is a drawdown for which not only the Member States but also the European Commission can.Commissioner, more effective measures must be taken here.The second comment is Brexit.It will, of course, have a major impact on drawing.The United Kingdom is the second largest recipient of Horizon 2020 subsidies, and I wonder: What is the impact on the perception of the EU in the Member States?How is it that the country with the second largest drawdown from Horizon 2020 has decided to leave the EU?We should think about that.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the implementation of Horizon 2020 has brought benefits. I don't think anyone can dispute that. It is the largest research program in the world, as it has been said, but it also aims to provide answers to social and economic challenges. I support the proposed change of the phrase "European Research Area" to "European Education and Research Area". We need an applied education. If we want the reindustrialization of Europe, if we want the development of SMEs, we need an applied education, education adequate to economic development. Industry innovation, research development in all fields can lead to a better life for people. After all, this is the purpose of research. There is a need to improve the approach of this program so that the result of research and innovation can be taken over, applied by SMEs much more easily. The mid-term evaluation of this program allows some recommendations to be made and I congratulate the rapporteur, but I want to emphasize a few things. I would like this Horizon 2020 program to have a greater impact on poorer areas and contribute more to social cohesion, and we need to support researchers. In many countries, researchers cannot apply their research results.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, investing in research, development and innovation is investing in the future of our children.Thanks to technological advances, the world is rapidly advancing, old statuses and wealth are becoming less and less important, and new markets are growing and suppressing old ones.Whoever does not keep pace is doomed to stagnation and long-term decline, and Europe must not allow itself to do so.I support Horizon 2020 because I believe that research and innovation are areas where public investment is necessary and justified.However, we also need to work on attracting private investment and I am so glad that the rapporteur has recognized this.But I cannot agree with the recommendation that we give priority to funding climate change research as the United States is considering budget cuts in this area.Our strategy for investing in research, development and innovation must be based on our needs and long-term goals, and not on the daily policies of other global actors.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Along with Erasmus, which is also an investment in people, the Horizon 2020 program is certainly one of the most important programs and also the most successful.We invest in innovation, in research.I would like to emphasize that I, too, want the Horizon investment program to be more ambitious, for all countries to achieve what Denmark, Sweden, Finland, as well as Austria and Germany achieve - 3% of GDP in research investment.The world’s most developed countries, such as South Korea and Japan, are investing even more.Another important thing is to invest in all countries, that is, to connect countries in different networks and in this way also test the mechanisms that are increasingly used today in smart specialization as a key principle of cohesion policy..And thirdly, Europe should also cash in on its own innovation and research in new jobs and in the faster development of Europe as a whole.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues, research, development and innovation are key to the future of European society, and money spent in this area should be seen as investment in the future, not as a cost. I welcome the fact that we have managed to get a solid majority for EUR 120 billion for the future Framework Programme 9 (FP9) to include a strong focus on Social Sciences and Humanities (SSH) to assert the open data principle, to balance fundamental research and innovation, to better involve small and medium-sized enterprises in collaborative projects and innovation. Moreover, I am satisfied by the fact that we highlighted the need for FP9 to strengthen societal progress and create growth and jobs. I support the call for the policies to remove barriers such as low salaries in order to avoid a brain drain. Finally, we must put a very strong focus on the need to have better synergies between Framework Programmes and other EU funds.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman! Horizon 2020 aims to build a European economy based on knowledge and innovation, thereby increasing the competitiveness of European markets and enterprises. Moreover, the program contributes to the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy and other important Community policies. It is without doubt the largest and most ambitious program of its kind in the world. This does not mean, however, that Horizon 2020 has no disadvantages. As mentioned in the report, the success rate of less than 14% is alarmingly low, which could directly affect the withdrawal of less experienced entities from the program. Another disturbing fact may be the tendency to move away from subsidies in favor of using loans, which in turn, in the case of research at such a high level of innovation, which is to revolutionize the current functioning of markets, poses a high risk for investors.
