Retaining grant funding, further simplifying and removing barriers to synergies between funds, as well as ensuring a balanced mix of small, medium and large projects, is one of the most important challenges we face for the future of Horizon 2020.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this very good discussion.  I will start with the words of Jerzy Buzek, who said: this is not expenditure, it is an investment in our future. The big challenge we have ahead is how to go round the countries and convince the governments that this is not expenditure, this is an investment and a priority for our future. If we do not do that, we will not thrive, we will not get to where we want to be. When you look today at the number of publications we have in Europe, you see that with 7% of the population we have more than 33% of the entire number of publications and articles. If you compare that with the year 2000, you see a very interesting phenomenon – that we have surpassed the United States in highly cited publications. That represents a huge opportunity for the future if we continue to invest in that future. I think it was Mr Torvalds who talked about the importance of added value. This year when Ben Feringa, of the Netherlands, received the Nobel Prize he said something that I think we have to keep in mind – that the only place in the world today where we still believe in the intuition of scientists is Europe. It is because we believed in the intuition of Ben Feringa that he was able to invent something, to create something, that will change life for future generations, and that is why he won the Nobel Prize. In the space of 10 years, the European Research Council has been able to support researchers who have won six Nobel Prizes, four Fields Medals and five Wolf Prizes. That is the added value that we all recognise, and I am very happy that, right across the House, every one of you recognises that. All of you raised the point of investment. How can we increase this investment? Ms Matias, Mr Buzek, Mr Telička, Mr van Miltenburg, Ms Kudrycka, Ms Van Bossuyt – all are asking for more, because we need more! As I said, just to keep on funding the very, very good projects we would need another EUR 60 billion, because we are funding just one out of four of the very good ones. I am with you and I thank you for being so up-front with the amounts you think would be the right ones for the future. I thank you so much. Then there was Ms Matias and Mr Marcellesi, who raised a point that is paramount for me, about gender and gender balance. I think we have been, somehow, an example. We have to improve, but it shows each time I meet with my advisory panels and I see that we have surpassed the 50% mark for women on those panels. We now have 53% on those advisory panels. It has increased from 33% in 1997, so here we are leading by example. A lot of scientists who are women and who come before those panels tell me they feel better when they see that there is gender balance in the room: there is a different energy and it produces different results. On the expert panels, we are not doing so well. We had a target, as you know, of 40% and unfortunately we are still at 37%. We have not achieved that target but we will fight for it. If you compare the results with those of the past, we are doing better. Is it enough in terms of gender? No, we are not doing enough. I want to do more and I hope that you can help me on that. Then we talked here about vision, and you repeated three words that for me are crucial: the word ‘excellence’, the word ‘openness’ and the word ‘impact’. I think it was Mr Zorrinho who said that excellence is when openness crosses impact, and that is exactly it. We need to be at that juncture. For the future we have to achieve the ability of looking at this programme in terms of a triangle. One axis is between the excellence that we need – because we need to be at the top, and for that we scale, speed and everybody working together – and then openness, because that, today, is our political statement. Openness is not just something that is natural for us, who love science. We know that there is no science without openness, there is no innovation without openness, there is no programme without being open to the world. Today it has become a political statement, and an important one. That is our difference, because we want to be open. The third factor is impact. Impact matters not just in commercial terms – the impact we know, the impact of the product – but also in terms of the impact of everything we do in fundamental research. That is the impact which will come in 10, 50 or 100 years’ time but which, we believe, will change the world at some point. I would like to thank Ms Cabezón Ruiz very much for the report and for her hard work. All of you give me the energy to keep doing my job, and that is really unique.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: speaker. - Mr President, I would like to conclude by highlighting some of the ideas that have been put forward here. Balance between all parties and all interests as a key and challenge that I think we have managed to capture in this report. Consensus as a basis for the credibility and trust that the scientific community needs and, subsequently, as a consequence, the progress of European society. Research as an engine of economic and social development, as excellence, but also cohesion. Adequate budget for projects with high European added value for society: let us guarantee a fair return on investment so that science reaches each and every European citizen. Gender and youth: this will need to be reinforced in the next framework program. If we want an excellent Europe, we need all its excellent regions, all the young people and, for this, it is necessary to start the entrepreneurial and research culture from the earliest ages and have all the potential and all the intelligence. For this reason, women have to be better reflected in the Horizon 2020 research program. We propose as a tiebreaker a study that determines which are the barriers that prevent it and, above all, that we also promote a framework in the Member States that allows to bring out the entire fabric of researchers with high-quality projects. But I want to end as I started, recognizing the potential and importance of this program, an enormously positive program and key to the future of Europe. Therefore, I think that the message that we have to have and that we have to end with is one of reinforcement and recognition of their success. Of course, I would like to reiterate my thanks to the shadow rapporteurs for the collaboration and the good atmosphere that this work has allowed and, of course, to offer collaboration to the Commissioner to continue working along the same lines.

ES. name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: in writing. – We welcome the report. It steers the Commission’s proposal on the next FP in the right direction. In particular, we appreciate that the report clearly endorses excellence as the key selection criteria. It is also important that the report underlines the role of fundamental research in H2020. We must as well ensure gender balance and transparency in this and following FPs.  I am delighted that the Industry, Research and Energy Committee (ITRE) adopted my proposal – in the context of the Paris Agreement – to prioritise funding for climate change research. ITRE also supported my proposal concerning the need to ensure that 100% of the energy challenge funds are allocated to green energy research and innovation. Hopefully, the plenary will do the same.  Unfortunately if we fail to amend the language on the defence research my Group will not be able to support the report. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and all those involved in this endeavour for constructive collaboration.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: signed up. - The gap between regions in terms of participation in Horizon 2020 is a major problem. I call on the Commission and, in particular, the agencies responsible for implementing the priority of scientific excellence to promote collaborations and coordination activities so as to encourage the participation of low-capacity regions by capacity building and to support mobility and professional development in those regions. The European Research Council should be involved in several collaborative projects in Europe and dedicate itself, in particular, to regions and institutions with low capacity, in order to spread EU R&D policies and know-how. throughout the European Union. I also believe that the budget lines of Horizon 2020, which were reduced in the period 2015-2020 to feed the EFSI, need to be redressed and that the EFSI should be funded from sources independent of the already approved EU programs. And last but not least, taking stock of the achievements of joint undertakings such as Clean Sky and SESAR and the ECSEL Joint Technology Initiatives, Shift2Rail, and the Joint Technology Initiatives for Bioindustries, I call on the Commission to extend the system to the next FP9 program. governance of joint technology initiatives in new industrial sectors, such as space technologies.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: signed up. - Horizon 2020 is the European Union's most important program to stimulate research and innovation at European level. Even if its objectives are positive, the implementation of the program so far indicates many structural problems. The first issue concerns the unequal treatment of different categories of applicants and beneficiaries. Furthermore, researchers from Eastern Europe are paid below the salary level of those from Western Europe, and this inequality is also reproduced in the evaluation of projects, with senior universities being additionally scored even if the projects and ideas of newer or Eastern European research institutions. they can be better. Another issue concerns the culture of consultancy stimulated by Horizon 2020. The structural lobby, traditional consortia and some consultants have reduced trust among applicants. Finally, a last problem reported is related to the slow pace of evaluation compared to the speed of innovation in the market. This is how the funds are received after the technology has become obsolete. All these issues need to be rectified in the perspective of FP9.

name: Kerstin WESTPHAL
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Let me tell you about a man from Franconia: Franz-Josef, 50 years old, physically disabled and unemployed for more than 20 years. Since last year he has been working as a commercial employee in a company near Nuremberg. The ESF made this possible. 20 long-term unemployed in the region have found a new job through the ESF. Why am I telling you this? The European Structural Funds make a lot possible. You are close to people and can actually make life worth living again. They create jobs, they help to cope with climate change, invest in research, build infrastructures and carry out cross-border projects. The structural funds are an engine for jobs and sustainable growth. We actually have to keep this engine running! The discussion about this has started. And I confess: I am worried. There are voices who want to reduce cohesion policy, and even want to abolish it. I can only strongly warn against that. Structural policy is not just a growth engine. It is also an expression of lived solidarity. Europe, this abstract being in Brussels, in Strasbourg, can actually be experienced and experienced locally through the structural funds. We can't let that ruin us! That is why I drafted this report together with the shadow rapporteurs. I believe that it is indeed a good report that presents reality and the value of cohesion policy in particular, but which at the same time puts its finger in the wound. Because of course there is a need for improvement. It starts with the bureaucracy. It cannot be that potential applicants are literally slain by forms and forms and then give up in exasperation and decide not to apply at all. Nor can it be that the administrative authorities suffer from constant fear of making some mistake and then being pilloried. We need a simplification of the rules. And we need more flexible rules. We and the regions must be able to respond to new challenges. Perhaps completely new challenges will be facing us in 2024, which we will also face and have to overcome with European structural funds. That is why we are calling for simple reprogramming in the report. To conclude, let me say something about tomorrow's vote. As I have already mentioned, the future of the structural funds is indeed at stake. I would like Parliament to send a clear, strong signal here in favor of maintaining cohesion policy. At the same time, our colleagues from REGI in particular know that there are two points of contention in the committee where our groups have very, very different views. One concerns macro-conditionality and the other the so-called “golden rule”. There will be amendments on both subjects tomorrow. I understand the wishes of the Greens as well as those of parts of my own group who are against macro-conditionality but do not want to mention it in the report. But I also know that macro conditionality has supporters in this House who even want to strengthen it. Dear colleagues, I therefore ask you very, very warmly: Let us fight this fight later! Let us send a strong signal tomorrow, to the Member States, to the Commission: We, the European Parliament, want a modern, financially strong, less bureaucratic cohesion policy. We want a cohesion policy for all regions, and we want a cohesion policy that is made for the people, with simpler procedures, with better results. With a strong signal we will be heard.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank all those who contributed to this initiative, the Communication Unit of DG REGIO, the representatives of the Committee of the Regions for their contributions, the secretariats of the political groups for support. and cooperation and, of course, shadow rapporteurs. The visibility of European investments and the increased communication of results have become a concern at the level of the European Union institutions. The report proposal comes with concrete ideas and tools adapted to increase the communication on structural funds. At the end of March, the Commission presented concrete proposals to Member States' ministers in Luxembourg to increase the visibility of cohesion policy. At the same time, an action plan on the methods of communicating cohesion policy is being prepared. At the same time, the Maltese Presidency acknowledged the lack of visibility of cohesion policy and confirmed the agreement at Council level on ways in which Member States can more clearly demonstrate that this policy has a direct and positive impact on the lives of EU citizens. We started in this report from the fact that visibility in cohesion policy, as well as funding opportunities are a responsibility of local and regional authorities. These are the interface closest to the citizen, benefiting, as we all know, from a high degree of trust. On the other hand, although cohesion policy is financed with a budget of over € 350 billion, the positive effects are known to a low degree by citizens, and the obvious conclusion was that communication methods have not always been the most effective. . As I pointed out in the content of the proposal, only a third of those surveyed in the 2015 Eurobarometer, and I point out, only a third, have heard of projects funded by cohesion policy and the positive effect on their lives. In this context, better coordination between public authorities, the social and economic partners and civil society is therefore needed, in order to communicate effectively the objectives of the European Union, in order to increase citizens' interest in belonging to the common European project. Together with my colleagues in the REGI Committee, I insisted that the proposal for an Omnibus regulation include a mandatory percentage in the technical assistance dedicated to advertising, given that the percentage values ​​currently used are very low, in some countries almost non-existent. At the same time, we called for a stricter set of requirements for the advertising of EU-funded projects, as it has been shown that a simple billboard attesting to the presence of investments through European funds is not enough. At the same time, we drew attention to the need to clarify the regulatory framework for communication tools, as there are many cases where beneficiaries avoid accessing these tools due to the lack of coherence of existing legislation and, of course, the fear of sanctions. what can happen later. In the long run, achieving the set objectives can only be achieved with the involvement of all relevant partners in the decision-making process. There is a need to develop tools or platforms for animation, taking into account current methods of participatory governance, by involving citizens in a participatory budgeting process. Increasingly open access to information confirms that citizens want to be asked about the appropriateness of development projects at the local community level. Adapted tools are therefore needed, given the technological developments and increasing public access to current digital media. Not in the last In conclusion, Mr President, a new objective proposed in the report is to outsource the outcome of cohesion policy in the context of the future communication strategy.The Commission should adopt different communication strategies for net contributing and net beneficiary Member States respectively.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: rapporteur. - The recent series of earthquakes in Italy has had a devastating effect on the affected areas. But it's not just these natural disasters that are happening in Europe - fires in Portugal, floods in Romania, just a few hours ago an earthquake in western Turkey, which affected southern Bulgaria and part of Greece. Large-scale restoration work is needed to help the population, especially in the Italian regions, to live in decent conditions and to preserve the cultural heritage of the affected regions. In addition to the initial support offered by the European Union Solidarity Fund, additional amounts could be provided to Member States by the European Regional Development Fund for the reconstruction of regions affected by major natural disasters. In order to provide such additional assistance to Member States affected by natural disasters, the general legal framework established for the European Structural and Investment Funds needs to be amended. The European Commission has proposed to amend Article 120 of the Regulation on generally applicable provisions by introducing a separate priority axis for reconstruction projects supported by the European Regional Development Fund under operational programs. The Commission has proposed that the co-financing rate be up to 100% for these projects. Operations selected by the managing authorities will be financed under the priority axis only if they relate to rehabilitation activities in response to a major or regional natural disaster, as defined in Regulation 2012/2002 establishing the Solidarity Fund. The proposal has no budgetary implications, with the proposed activities remaining within the total amount allocated for the period 2014-2020, with the whole package remaining unchanged. The report I am presenting today supports the Commission's proposal as a focused and budget-neutral solution. He points out that the policy of Cohesion must adapt to new challenges and ensure a rapid response from all Member States whose regions are affected by major natural disasters. As a result of interinstitutional negotiations, the European Parliament and the Council reached a political agreement on the Commission's legislative proposal. This was followed with great support for the proposal in the Committee on Regional Development. In this regard, I propose to you an amendment to the Commission's legislative proposal, which includes, on the one hand, support through the European Regional Development Fund up to 95% co-financing under an operational program, but on the other hand retains the proposals in Parliament's initial report. a threshold of 5% on the national allocation of the European Regional Development Fund to the Member State concerned. The political agreement we have reached is an expression of our solidarity. It shows our understanding that we are all vulnerable, that a natural disaster is possible in any region, and that we should support each other in tackling these challenges by offering support to rehabilitate the affected areas. I would like to draw your attention in the context of today's debate on cohesion policy, that cohesion policy must adapt to new challenges. As in this case, to be able to ensure a rapid, adequate response to all Member States whose regions are affected by natural disasters. A simple, effective and efficient procedure for responding to unforeseen circumstances must be established. That is what the Commission is doing with its proposal, that is what we are proposing with this report that I am presenting today.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, let me start by thanking Parliament’s Committee on Regional Development, the Chair Iskra Mihaylova for organizing this meeting, as well as honorable Members Kerstin Westphal and Daniel Buda for their reports. As regards Ms Kerstin Westphal’s report on building blocks for a post-2020 EU cohesion policy, the Commission welcomes their valuable contribution to current reflections on the future of Europe and to the next multiannual financial framework. This is a very timely input, in particular in view of our Cohesion Forum at the end of June. The Commission shares most of the views of this report. In particular, we believe, as you believe, that cohesion policy is more necessary than ever. As all three rapporteurs have underlined here, the European Union is facing tough challenges, such as globalization, migration, which go beyond national borders, and this is where the European Union’s cohesion policy can make a difference. Cohesion policy, as Ms Westphal said, empowers thousands of stakeholders throughout the European Union to tap into each region’s potential and make the best of innovation and smart specialization, making sure that every EU region, no matter whether it is north, south, east or west, is better armed and resilient against globalization, making sure that every European Union citizen can have access to the same opportunities. So this policy works, but for the future it needs to strike a balance between change and stability, keeping what works, carefully assessing the costs and benefits of changes, providing the incentives for targeted structural reforms, to ease the link between investment, growth and jobs, enabling all funds to closely work together and exploiting to the greatest possible extent the potential for simplification. But I hope you all agree with me that this is not enough. Our policy delivers, but we also have to make sure that EU citizens are aware of that. There is a long tradition in communicating the cohesion policy but now we need to do even better. And that links me to the next report by Mr Buda but I shall not continue without once again thanking Ms Westphal, and also the shadow rapporteurs and all the team who worked on this report, for their efforts and their contributions. I shall now switch to my language because the rapporteur is Romanian. The European Commission also greatly appreciates Mr Buda's report on strengthening partner engagement and the visibility of European Structural and Investment Funds. Like you, all our studies, as you pointed out, all our studies show that a lot of people are not yet informed about what the European Union is doing for them, despite the long-term investment of all schools. of hospitals and jobs created. And, I said once again, we come from the same region, I only discovered by running for the position of European parliamentarian that in Cluj-Napoca the tram lines are sponsored by European funds. I think we need to make a collective effort. Also, in Sofia, last week, we expanded the metro line and I don't think that many citizens in Sofia know that they already benefit and go with the metro in Sofia co-financed in proportion of 95% of European funds. So I think we need to make a bigger effort. We are in a situation, I might say, sometimes dramatic. Despite these investments, we know very well that this cohesion policy is more under attack than ever. This is no secret to anyone. That is why I am glad that we have this report, I am glad that we have agreed on the need to increase communication on European funds and what these European funds do for the daily lives of citizens. As you have shown, we are all concerned about the lack of visibility of cohesion policy. You asked for this Today, together with Commissioner Thyssen, we set out to join forces with the Member States and strengthen our investment profile. This was also the message I sent last week to the Informal Ministerial Council in Malta in the presence of all ministers in the 28 Member States. Communication on cohesion policy is a common responsibility, so it should be a joint effort. The European Commission cannot be the only one to act in this regard. You know very well that in any country I go, I visit as many projects as I can as a person, but the Member States, the Parliament, the Committee of the Regions, local and regional authorities, civil society should also contribute. And I know a lot of you do that. I believe that we need to tell, to share the success stories of the millions of small and medium-sized enterprises that have benefited in the last ten years from aid from European funds. We should talk more about entrepreneurs whose dreams are finally coming true, about mothers who can finally find work thanks to European funds, thanks to the new opportunities offered by the labor market. In fact, I think I should mention some promising initiatives that have already been launched, such as the German success story brochure or the "Let stars shine, engage in citizens, in the EU" communication plan, let the stars shine. , involving citizens on the present and future of the European Union, drafted by nine Members of Parliament led by Mr Lambert van Nistelrooij. But I count on your support and ideas to ensure that this policy will be good news for 500 million Europeans. I have taken note of your proposals. I want you to know that even in the operational programs they existed money for communication. I think it would not be useless to see how this money, intended for communication, was spent for each operational program, especially for large programs. As you said, I think we need more clarity, more transparency, to see what communication means, what advertising means and of course here we have to rely a lot on the support of our colleagues in the media, who should help us. with the publication of these success stories. Finally, concerning natural disasters, I would like to warmly thank this House and Madam Chair Iskra Mihaylova for your efforts to reach a swift agreement on natural disasters despite the difficulties. So now we will be able to help the Member States cover from the Structural Funds 95% of all the damage caused by natural disasters. As we speak, there is an earthquake in Greece. Last year it was Italy, and we expressed our sympathy for the people in Italy. Now, we have an earthquake in the Aegean Sea in Greece, in Chios and Lesbos, Aegean islands which I will visit as from tomorrow. Especially in this time of crisis: they are all hit by the migrant crisis, and now we have this earthquake. My sympathies go to the people of Greece especially, today. As I said, this dossier has an important political significance. We wanted from the very beginning to send a clear political signal that Europe cares about its citizens and that it is willing and able to provide help quickly. As I said, yesterday it was Italy, today it is Greece, tomorrow it could be Sweden or other countries. Therefore, it was important to urgently conclude an agreement and I believe that, under these circumstances, the compromise reached is reasonable. Thank you, and of course I am looking forward to our debate.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - Commissioner! Mr. Chairman! The debate in the European Parliament on the future of cohesion policy takes place at a very important moment. Firstly, the European Parliament has started work on the future financial perspective and we are very closely following what is happening in the Commission and we are looking forward to the reflection paper that the Commissioner and Commissioner Oettinger are preparing at the end of June. We are very interested in what will appear in this document that will have an impact on future actions. At the same time, several governments important in Europe have spoken about cohesion policy, and this is also closely followed by Parliament. The lessons from Malta are extremely important to us, because the work in Malta has indeed attempted to translate the scenarios for the future for cohesion policy. This is the first attempt of this type to show what are the tangible consequences of individual solutions concerning the European Union. The discussion on the future of the European Union is actually a discussion today about the European Union in general, what the European Union is to be, what its policies are to be, how it is supposed to function. The question of the very shape of the cohesion policy is partly fundamental, partly technical, because on the one hand we know well that cohesion policy is the key to the European Union, and on the other hand we know that, for example, no changes can be made in the next perspective, what the Commissioner said, because the delays in this perspective are so long that we cannot afford to reinvent new methods and new solutions. Today, the most important thing for us is simplification, simplification, and for us the most important thing is to answer the question what, from today's perspective of the cohesion policy, should be strengthened and extended, and this is actually the key to the whole matter and it will be an argument for maintaining this policy in future.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Mr President, Commissioner, only 34% of Europeans say they have heard of projects co-financed by the European Union to improve their region, the region in which they live. However, these projects are numerous. They are essential for regional and social cohesion and they have an important role in reducing disparities. It is essential to give more visibility to these projects, because they are the concrete image of the action of the European Union. It is and remains important to communicate on the European added value of the projects which are financed. As rapporteur on this dossier for Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I underline the effects of these projects in terms of job creation and social integration. It is also important to reduce the administrative burden, without reducing controls, in order to allow easier access for small and medium-sized enterprises, in particular those located in rural areas. Finally, I stress the importance of ensuring the participation of social partners and actors on the ground. They must be able to be involved in the various stages of programming, implementation as well as monitoring and evaluation of the use of these funds.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! The report on the components of cohesion policy post-2020 is intended to be the European Parliament's contribution to the discussion on its future priorities. I consider it extremely important that we have a clear and common position. There is no doubt that the cohesion policy is one of the pillars of the European Union and, as a unique tool on a global scale, is a brand and an EU trademark in our cities and regions. It was thanks to it that the effects of the crisis were mitigated and now investments are being stimulated again. That is why we want to strongly communicate: the cohesion policy after 2020 must retain its important place in the EU budget, constituting at least the same part of it as in the current financial perspective, as it is beneficial for the entire EU economy. Obviously, although the cohesion policy is doing its job well, it is important to keep working on maximizing its potential. Hence the important proposals for further procedural simplification and, above all, and, I always emphasize, greater flexibility, so that it can better react to unforeseen events, and that local and regional authorities have the opportunity to freely adapt it to local priorities and realities. I also urge us to be aware that cohesion policy is an integral part of the entire European economy. Therefore, a balanced approach to its link with economic governance processes should be maintained.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, as shadow rapporteur I wanted to say a few words on the Natural Disasters Agreement. We started discussions with differences between Parliament, the Council and the Commission. And indeed, there are also differences between the political groups within this Parliament. So it is a huge achievement but we managed to get a common position in Parliament and then a compromise agreement with the Council. Now, of course, it is important that the money goes to Italy as soon as possible, so the people there can benefit from these Structural Funds.  I also wanted to say a few words on the future of cohesion policy. I want to thank the rapporteur for her report and the Commissioner for her excellent words. I think we  in this Parliament can actually learn something from our discussions on the national disasters issue. We were much stronger in those negotiations because we were united and therefore we also need to be united in our position on the future of cohesion policy. If we are united and speak with one voice it will be much more difficult for others to ignore us.  I would say that, at this stage, we should not be talking about detailing too much. Detail can come much later, because at the moment there is so much on which we can agree with, we need to agree an adequate budget cohesion policy, that all regions should get something, that there should be more for poorer Member States. We should agree on simplification, we should agree that there should be a greater focus on performance, but the main thing today is to agree this report and to start the fight for the future of cohesion policy.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Mr. President, the basic idea of ​​the European Union is open political cooperation and free economic exchange between countries that are naturally directed at each other, share the same values ​​and want to achieve the same goals in the future. For this to be possible, European nation-states must have approximately similar starting positions, because otherwise the old animosities and the feeling that in this relationship there are those who profit and those who have been exploited will be awakened. If we get to that point, the idea of ​​European integration will be seriously jeopardized. The key role of cohesion policy is precisely to ensure a similar starting position for all, despite the different historical circumstances in which the current Member States have developed. The goal is to create a Europe of equal opportunities on the principle of solidarity, and we must not give up on that. Cohesion policy must be preserved despite political crises such as Brexit, it must be free of administrative barriers and simplified as much as possible. We need to integrate funds from different funds and prepare programs in advance at the level of regions and Member States so that bad experiences from the previous financial period are not repeated. I also support the strengthening of administrative capacity, but I emphasize that this must not mean increasing the scope of the administration, but increasing its efficiency. We must avoid further bureaucratization at all costs!

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Today we discuss the building blocks for achieving a cohesion policy beyond 2020. A cohesion policy 2.0. But let's keep the benefits of current policy, such as the ex-ante conditions and thematic concentration. For example, after 2020, all regions in Europe should still be eligible for resources from structural and investment funds. After all, they put the European strategy of growth and sustainability into practice. Whether that strategy is called Europe 2020 or soon Europe 2030, Brexit may mean that cohesion policy will have to do it after 2020 with fewer resources. This also means that we have to focus even more on results in cohesion policy. Therefore, a strong link should be established with necessary structural reforms in the lagging countries and regions, a link should be established with the follow-up of country-specific recommendations, with the care for good economic governance by establishing a balanced link between cohesion policy and the European Semester, while maintaining macroeconomic conditionality and respecting commitments from the Stability and Growth Pact. This is necessary for the ALDE group to be able to make a good return on the euros that we invest with cohesion policy. We also see the further development of cohesion policy after 2020 as an opportunity. An opportunity to add a stronger urban dimension. An opportunity to continue on the path of simplifying the funds. An opportunity to give Interreg more clout, so that cohesion policy remains the investment policy after 2020 for cohesion in Europe with smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the last summit, which took place in Valletta, reinforces our concerns, since four of the five scenarios that have been presented herald deep cuts for the post-2020 period. Added to this budgetary concern is the concern about what we hear from Member States like Germany, for example, which purely and simply evokes the possibility of calling into question the categories of regions, which is very serious . In fact, the reality is that regional policy has become heavily attacked and is now doomed to be distorted. Denatured, it is already by the surveillance and punishment measures that are macroeconomic conditionalities; distorted, it still is when it comes to playing this role of adjustment variable of the European Semester; distorted, it will also be so, if financial instruments were to replace subsidies. We don’t want all of this, and the less developed regions don’t want it either. What we want is a major regional policy anchored in solidarity, effective, faithful to its vocation assigned by the treaties. More than ever, the European Union needs a major policy of solidarity. This is the meaning of the Westphal report and this is what we need to work on together.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr. President, cohesion policy is not just an exchange of money, it is a lived European solidarity. Cohesion policy can change the livelihoods of millions of citizens in the European Union, create a better life for the many, not just the few – if it is done well. Cohesion policy can let this continent grow together much faster and closer than before, but it can also tear it apart and that’s why we need to make it better. First of all, we need to invest in the future. Big money, big business will not solve the problems that Europe is facing today. That is why we do not just need any investment but sensible investments to fight inequality, to create jobs, to revolutionise our energy systems and to create a sustainable economy. Secondly, we should not punish those who actually need our support the most. Sometimes in politics we hide behind technical terms to cover up problems and controversies. ‘Macroeconomic conditionality’ is one of those terms. Most Europeans probably don’t even know what this means and there are some politicians who actually don’t want them to know what it means, because they can have a devastating effect on their lives. It is very often punishing those countries who are in most need of European support. And anyway, why should a local NGO supporting long-term unemployed people pay for the possible mistakes that their government have been making. Macroeconomic conditionality is simply wrong, and this Parliament has been opposed to macroeconomic conditionality in the past and we should keep up this fight even if the Council and Commission are pushing us to change our position. Lastly, we need to gear up the fight against fraud and corruption. Cohesion policy is not only about economic and social affairs, it goes deeply into questions of rule of law. We cannot have Europeans losing trust in the whole system because of those who are undermining its credibility. That is why we need a functioning European Public Prosecutor and mechanisms to end corruption. Yes, there are forces in the Council who want to get rid of cohesion policy altogether, but instead of being afraid of them we should pick up this battle; we should stand up and tell them: ‘Bring it on!’ We are ready to fight for cohesion policy for the future.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, finally a debate on the future of cohesion policy, on post-2020 cohesion policy, also in plenary. In committee, our vote on this report was favorable, thanks above all to the exclusion of national co-financing from the Stability and Growth Pact, as we have been calling for since the beginning of the legislature. However, this paragraph is now heavily in jeopardy due to an amendment tabled by PPE, ALDE and S & amp; D. While the Großkoalition makes amendments that bury our economies, the 5 Star Movement makes others for the citizens, against macro-conditionality, against the possibility of suspending funds if your absurd country-specific recommendations are not carried out. Colleagues, if as Parliament we are not able to approve the proposal of the golden rule on investments, which dares to criticize the perverse mechanism of macro-conditionality, how can we negotiate with the Council the defense of the future cohesion policy? How can we present ourselves in front of the regions, municipalities and citizens whose projects risk being suspended and not planned, because governments would not have respected absurd rules? A little courage, colleagues, the courage you had in voting for structural reforms. Have the same courage to go against the imposed austerity measures. Let us wake up and give signs of our existence as co-legislators, before it is too late, before cohesion policy is canceled by Katainen and Dombrovskis ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Today I actually wanted to talk about the waste of cohesion funds, but current events have caught up with me. Recently it was already hit with the lease of the Medicines Agency. There it turned out that the goochemists of the EU had concluded a lease for 30 years, without an early termination option. And of course not just any neighborhood, it was Canary Wharf. Costs for the taxpayer: 350 million euros. And today another beautiful one: the Paul-Henri Spaak building in Brussels, you know, is about to collapse after 24 years and the costs for the new building: 340 million euros. Who will pay for it? The taxpayer. If the EU is not even able to put up a decent office building with the nose on top, how on earth is it capable of running 27 EU countries? Then there is the Anti-Fraud Office OLAF, which discovered no less than € 631 million worth of fraud in 2015. It just goes to show that the EU's waste of money is not limited to cohesion funds. I hope that we all end this as soon as possible and that we can get back to working on useful matters.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, the founding treaties of the European Union aim to promote the development of our peoples, emphasizing that economic integration must also help to raise living standards. The most important tool for this is cohesion policy. According to the report, after 2008, disparities between Member States and regions have widened sharply, and social and economic inequalities have become more severe. The differences are sharp in wages. The population of the countries that joined 13 years ago judges primarily on this basis that the so-called "EU project" is successful or unsuccessful. The wage gap within the Union is not good for developed countries either. Millions of less developed countries are being forced to take a living in the developed world for a living, pushing down wages and causing social tensions. Recognizing this, the Jobbik for Hungary movement launched the European Citizens' Initiative, which aimed to catch up with European wages by finding partners in seven countries. The European Commission has embraced this initiative, recognizing its legitimacy and committing itself to initiating legislation when one million signatures are collected. An important area for this could be a new cohesion policy that supports human resource development and high value-added companies, and thus wage growth itself.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on active cohesion policies that affect our territories and concern the credibility of the European Union, I intervene in particular with reference to the aspect of the Solidarity Fund and with reference to the financing to be dedicated to earthquake areas. I believe that it is central, within this context, to support and direct our dedication and our attention to those who have lived and are living dramatic moments because it is not just the human aspect that prevails over everything, but it is about a system, the economic one, of our small and medium enterprises, of our agricultural system, of our shopkeepers and our artisans, who lose hope and have to move from their places of origin, without the possibility of understanding what the perspective is. I believe that, with this type of policy, the European Union is moving closer to our territories and therefore to cohesion policy.

name: Constanze KREHL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! With Mrs Westphal's report, we as Parliament would like to express a strong position on the future of European cohesion policy. We need that in order to be able to be strong in the negotiations. But we also need it to support the Commissioner in her commitment to a real, good cohesion policy, not to a rump cohesion policy program. We need this investment program as an opportunity for solidarity between all regions, and in every direction. We have to give support in the fight against unemployment, above all against the far too high youth unemployment. We need investments in the fight against poverty. And of course it makes the most sense to really promote sustainable, modern economic development and, above all, to give support to small and medium-sized companies. Let me add one more comment on this: above all, we must also support start-ups that cannot raise risk capital on their own, where it is really only the European Union that is ready to invest. I was in northern Sweden last week and found excellent examples of exactly where this is being implemented. In a sparsely populated region, ideas for the future are supported and implemented, creating jobs and perspectives for a region that may have sometimes thought that it was a little far away from Brussels and a little left behind. We have to implement this for all regions. Incidentally, Germany is in favor of a cohesion policy that supports all regions. If there is a misunderstanding - that is the current situation, and we fight and argue for it in Germany. We need infrastructure, we need the fight against climate change, we need research and innovation, we need good ones Ideas.And that is why we as members of parliament, as representatives of the electorate, must fight for this cohesion policy and stand up for what really has a positive effect on people's daily lives.Let us vote for this report tomorrow by a large majority!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the European Union's cohesion policy must support countries that have suffered huge economic losses as a result of the crisis. This mainly concerns the countries of the European periphery, and especially Greece, which suffers from austerity and violent fiscal adjustment policies. In addition, the European Union must formulate a policy of effective compensation for the cohesion countries that have been damaged by earthquakes, such as the damage caused a few hours ago in Lesvos by the catastrophic earthquake of 6.1 Richter. At the same time, Mrs Creţu, there must be generous compensation for the huge landslide damage at PPC's Amyntaio lignite mine on Saturday, where the damage amounted to at least 1 billion euros. 25 million tonnes of lignite, worth 500 million euros, were literally buried under tons of mud, as were four 80 million euro excavators. Therefore, serious measures must be taken to deal with these disasters as well.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, cohesion policy’s title sounds different in all official EU languages but the meaning remains very much the same. A more accelerated national economic and social development, more rapid economic growth and increasing employment: this is the value added of cohesion policy.  Cohesion policy encourages solidarity between EU regions and contributes to the strengthening of the EU single market. It is therefore beneficial not only for the less, but also for the more, developed Member States. In future, cohesion policy should be more flexible, while at the same time based on reasonable conditionalities. While implementing long-term investment goals it should also be able to contribute to meeting the new challenges. For example, to ease the effects of the economic and financial crisis, to react to migration and refugees’ integration challenges, to deal with climate change, the digital agenda, innovation demand and energy safety issues, amongst many.  In order to retain its attractiveness cohesion policy should also be more simplified in all areas such as audit, state aid, public procurement and financial instruments, and I hope it is all achievable.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Commissioner, the message of the European Parliament is strong and clear: cohesion policy must not only continue after 2020, but must also be strengthened, because social and regional disparities have increased in recent years, as has unemployment, poverty and the distance between rich and poor countries, rich and poor regions. Without a strong cohesion policy, without practical European solidarity, the European perspective itself is at stake. Because when we all work together for something, but the rich get richer and the poor get poorer, then the European Union itself will face the risk of a catastrophic crisis. And, of course, less bureaucracy and more transparency are needed to tackle corruption. But you have a strong ally, Commissioner, in the European Parliament, because you know very well that, both within the Commission and even more so in the Council, there are forces that want to weaken cohesion policy. The earthquakes that took place a few hours ago in Greece, such as a while ago in Italy, the landslide of a huge lignite mine in Northern Greece yesterday, show the need to strengthen the European Solidarity Mechanism. Especially for my country, which is suffering from many years of austerity and a seven-year recession, European funds, and not just European crocodile tears, must be used to reduce human and social suffering, to create jobs. The European North must show its solidarity not only in the European South but also in Eastern Europe by strengthening and not undermining cohesion policy.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, this report highlights an increase in euro-scepticism and anti-EU reporting, which the rapporteurs claim distorts information on EU policies. In other words, it raises alarm bells at the obvious fact that, just as happened to the Roman Empire, the wheels are starting to come off the EU chariot. You rightly understand that this rise in populism throughout the EU isn’t going away, and is a threat to the existence of the EU institutions. So how do you respond? By expressing the desire to waste more taxpayers’ money on dead-end projects and pro-EU political soundbites. This strikes me as a case of ‘thou doth protest too much’ and underlines that, in these times of austerity, the taxpayer has found you out. Indeed, with just 34% of citizens claiming to have heard about EU co-financed projects, it underlines how these projects are not doing much to help at all, yet you still call for more money to be wasted. As Abraham Lincoln famously said: ‘You can fool all of the people some of the time, and some of the people all of the time, but you can’t fool all of the people all of the time.’

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). - Mr President, contrary to what the reports we are discussing here today claim, in fact, cohesion policy is being called into question. It has not been realized that cohesion does not only depend on infrastructure projects or large investments, but, on the contrary, concerns the daily lives of European citizens. In this area, it is easy to see that the life of the average citizen of Western and Northern Europe has nothing to do with the life of the average citizen of Eastern and Southern Europe. With a very clear responsibility of the European institutions, the citizens of Greece, for example, are experiencing the daily deterioration of their standard of living, while, at the same time, the German economy continues to benefit from it. But beyond the unequal distribution, the methodical and premeditated undermining of national sovereignty in favor of a poorly controlled Brussels bureaucracy also plays an important role. I believe that we must pursue a mode of operation which focuses on the autonomy of the states, drastically cuts the Union budget, and the European institutions simply coordinate, where necessary, the co-operation of sovereign independent states, which, of course, know best the needs of their citizens.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, for me the Cohesion Policy is close to a miracle. For the first time in human history, in peacetime, independent, sovereign countries are contributing to other countries’ prosperity voluntarily on a systemic basis. That has never happened before. This is more than bridges. This is more than highways. This is more than metro lines. This is our nature, this is our beliefs. And the only way to let the stars shine is by not taking even one step back from this nature, not even one step back from these beliefs. I am glad that the proposal for the draft budget 2018 for European cohesion is the biggest in European history in terms of commitments, and I am glad that there is an increase of more than 20% foreseen for payments for Cohesion Policy. Today, now, is the right moment to show the European citizens that Europe is stronger than ever, no matter what crises are hitting our Union.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I wanted to thank my colleague Buda and the other rapporteurs of this report on communication of the ESI Funds for the work we have done together and for the climate we have worked with. A work that has further highlighted the fact that there is a serious communication deficit between European institutions and citizens. Citizens do not have the right perception of what Europe does for them, for the territory in which they live, as claimed by local administrations, regions. Victim of communication instrumental to the political game of populist movements, Europe is today unfortunately perceived as just a set of rules, limits, vetoes and bureaucracy that hinders the growth of the member states. Only a small part of the European population, for example, is familiar with cohesion policy. Many have heard of European funds, but few can describe what is being done with these funds. Still, cohesion policy is the main European investment policy. It intervenes massively on the weakest territories. I am thinking, for example, of my region, Sicily, which is a major beneficiary of the structural funds. Improving communication of the successes and objectives achieved by cohesion policy means rediscovering the link with citizens, giving clear and real information, showing concrete examples of how Europe is our first opportunity for growth and this, the Commissioner knows. well, it serves as a reminder to those who want to destroy cohesion policy that we cannot afford it.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: - Mister President!Let's not fool ourselves!It is not just the Brexit negotiations that are being used to attack cohesion policy or to make it available.Let me get back to the point here: Cohesion policy, as the only solidarity-based instrument for the equalization of living conditions so far, is non-negotiable for us.We need at least three maxims so that it can expand its solidarity basis after 2020.First: The EU structural funds are not suitable as a penal and coercive instrument.Above all, they should also create a balance in the southern member states.Secondly, I call on the Commission again to finally get rid of the macroeconomic conditions that are still clinging to the fund and which in fact prevent it from being sustainable.Thirdly, the escalating financial instruments in regional and structural funding have so far been unsuitable for launching projects and innovations in the municipalities.

name: Laura AGEA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would have liked to speak off the cuff in this meeting, but in reality I am involved, we are emotionally involved, I am Umbrian and I have experienced the dramatic situation of the earthquake. This question, once again, has highlighted how much this Europe moves mountains with gossip, but with actions it is unable, months after the earthquake in Italy, to remove even the rubble of the affected areas. Thousands of citizens, who are our friends, our relatives, our acquaintances, are still waiting to be among the winners of the temporary houses, as if having them were part of a prize competition. Small houses that are not there yet or are there closed and unused. And while their gentlemen, with great fanfare, came down to Norcia to give solidarity and support to the affected population, up here in Brussels, as if taken by doubling of personality, they asked for rigorous and mandatory respect for stability, in the name of which they are willing to sacrifice the life and dignity of human beings who have lost everything. Nothing can be done against the rigor of the hawks of austerity policies, nothing stirs your cold consciences. You force us to bend, convinced that we are right. Until God forbid, one day you too will have to deal with an ecosystem that does not look to the stability of public finances, but breaks down mercilessly and brings only destruction. That day, which we wish you will never arrive, you will understand what it means to lose everything and be alone.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). - Commissioner, before I begin my position, I would like to inform you that I am asking an urgent question as to whether my homeland, Greece, is entitled to money from the Solidarity Fund for the enormous natural disaster suffered by the mine at Amyntaio, which is estimated at one billion euros. In our case now, the question we are discussing here today is how visible cohesion policy is. Especially now that the Structural Funds are in the spotlight and many are preparing to cut their budgets because of Brexit. That is to say, how much are the contributing Member States willing to cover the amount corresponding to the cohesion budget in order to pay for the projects for which they have committed? Improving communication, in this context, is essential. It is necessary and urgent because it needs specific funding under technical assistance. It is essential that managing authorities request and communicate specific information from beneficiaries at all stages. Finally, it is necessary to involve all actors - universities, small and medium-sized enterprises, municipalities, regions - so that there is a joint evaluation and joint promotion of results in society.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is clear that the challenge we face is within the ability to improve the perception of local communities about the socio-economic impact of cohesion policies and above all of its results. A democratic management that involves the territories, the partnership and the institutional supply chain for a more precise and widespread information on strategies and tools and therefore also on the results. In particular, I want to underline the strategic value of the finalization of the European Social Fund, as resources are really a lever to increase the skills and training of disadvantaged people and therefore to improve active employment policies, so that they become known tools. to promote social inclusion. Therefore more communication, more information, more simplification, imagining effective tools also for a less empirical evaluation of the results, within a system of institutional hierarchies that share the vision.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, cohesion policy was and is an aid to convergence and one of the highest forms of European solidarity. It has reduced asymmetries and inequalities, but it has also been able to diagnose the specific needs of each region and what remains to be done. That is why cohesion policy is a place close to the citizens, hence it has been a valuable help during times of crisis and austerity. It was European aid that gave them and continues to give them hope. That is the policy, it is to help those who need it most and only in this way can we maintain this Union. Cohesion policy does serve this purpose. Let it be clear that no deputy, I think, agrees with the penalty through European funds, but that should be discussed elsewhere, at another time and should be the subject of an open and frank reflection among all of us. Therefore, we will talk about this at another time because that is not the issue we are debating today and it is also important to give a signal to local and national authorities of their role in publicizing European investment. That after 2020 we will be able to maintain the commitment to economic, social and territorial cohesion and the strengthening of European citizenship. That in 2020 there will be more and better intervention in the fight against unemployment, a better integration of migrants and that there will be a greater investment in small and medium-sized companies and that we continue to fight for the health of our planet. Sustainability, integration and solidarity: this is what distinguishes this Union.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, cohesion policy has long marked the European integration project and is among the most valid European policies, on par with the single market and the monetary union. Over the years, from a mere economic tool it has developed into one of the EU’s most widely—recognisable policies and a powerful symbol intra—EU solidarity. I believe there are a number of prerequisites for cohesion policy to guard its essential role in the European project and to remain strong and effective in the post 2020 period. It should continue to be the strongest financial pillar for infrastructure projects for less endowed countries, as these are the bases without which there cannot be economic development. It should keep the central role of grants and remain the most suitable instrument for types of interventions and it should have its lead role in long-term development in Member States reinforced and its relationship with other additional financial vehicles, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments, clarified.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the strategic lines for the post-2020 cohesion policy will be decided in the coming months, choices that will have a decisive impact on the future challenges and needs of the Union. Above all, an adequate budget must be maintained, taking into account the different levels of competitiveness of the regions, in order to achieve harmonious development of the European Union. Some reforms introduced in the past programming cycle, such as thematic concentration and ex ante conditionality, have helped to demonstrate the value of cohesion policy and must be maintained, but the mechanism of macroeconomic conditionality, which is in profound contradiction with the objective of these policies. For the same reason, I fully agree with the proposal to separate the national co-financing installments from the calculation of the deficit according to the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact. Finally, the method of involving the stakeholders concerned should be reviewed. The role of the socio-economic partnership will have to assume, especially in the programming phase, a binding weight and a form of systematic involvement for the added value that it can guarantee in the effective implementation of cohesion policies.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the cohesion strategy maintained over many years by generations of Europeans requires continuation and, preferably, intensification.This human and financial investment is a decisive contribution to the Union's competitiveness and the quality of life of millions of Europeans.They have been decisive for the trajectory of socio-economic convergence of the outermost regions with the European average, including the Azores, from which I come.In the same vein comes the proposal for specific support for natural disasters.Living on islands of volcanic origin in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean, as is my case, is a positive experience, but subject to natural risks.The measures proposed here will increase our security and it is in this planned and voluntary solidarity that I find one of the real reasons for the European Union to exist.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I begin with what I wanted to say at the end: you have found that you have support in Parliament. We need to continue this policy, I really appreciate what you are doing and all the effort you have to convince both the Commission and the Council that we need it. Cohesion policy primarily expresses the solidarity of the European Union as one of the fundamental principles of the European Union and we all know that, in fact, convergence has not been achieved, that we have areas where we have social and economic inequalities. That is why I want to appreciate all the reports and I want to refer in particular to the Westphal report. Our rapporteur has defined very well: we need a de-bureaucratised cohesion policy after 2020, for all regions and for the people. That is why I hope that this cohesion policy will be improved as a matter of principle and that we must not have conditionalities, we must have a uniform development in all regions. Thank you and congratulations to all the rapporteurs.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - In recent years, cohesion policy has helped the world a number of useful projects important for the development of structurally weaker regions. Nevertheless, we should not approach cohesion policy without further context. One of them is, for example, the outflow of profits, which in the case of the Czech Republic is estimated at tens of billions of crowns every year. These are also finances that are missing from the budget. Our efforts should therefore be geared towards real economic convergence, including wage convergence, without which further inequalities and problems for the functioning of the EU's internal market will inevitably arise. The positive presentation of the results of the Structural Funds does not depend on the size of the boards and the number of PR articles. People just have to see that European money goes to the things that are really needed. Rather than a small presentation of the good, it is the existence of some bad examples that does the Structural Funds and the whole of cohesion policy a disservice. However, this does not mean that we as a whole should question it in any way or relativize its significance and contribution.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I will say a few words in English and then in my mother tongue. Thank you very much for your contribution to our debate today and thank you very much for your support for the Cohesion Policy. I think these three reports came at a key moment for Europe and in particular for the Cohesion Policy. Discussions on the future will continue and intensify in the coming months. Ms Westphal’s report, together with the reflection paper on the social dimension, globalization and Europe, provide valuable food for thought. You know very well that we are working together, Mr Oettinger and I, on a reflection paper on the future of EU finances which will be presented at the end of this month. As was underlined here, I think we must, however, understand that the very best argument for strengthening this policy consists of actually making tangible progress on implementation. So we are working hand-in-hand with Member States to speed up the implementation on the ground because this year is of high political importance, it is not business as usual. It is very important to show that Member States are able to use this Cohesion Fund. There is no better argument for the future than a convincing present. It is our responsibility to do it. Make people aware of what the European project has brought them in 70 years of peace, how it has helped improve their daily lives. Of course much has been done so far but I am sure together we can still do better. Many ideas are now on the table, in particular those very helpful proposals by Mr Buda in his report about communication. The Commission is ready to do its part but it cannot do it alone. Please join forces with us and become ambassadors of the Cohesion Policy in your constituency. On natural disasters, I will say some words in Romanian. First of all, Mrs Spyraki, Mr Papadimoulis and Mr Marias, I have said from the beginning that I express my sympathy for the Greek people. I am aware of this natural disaster, earthquakes taking place in the Aegean Sea in recent days. I have changed the schedule: tomorrow I will be in Athens, the day after tomorrow I will visit Chios, Lesbos and the affected islands. You know very well that we in the European Commission have proposed 100% co-financing for natural disasters. I would like to thank Mrs Mihaylova, and I would like to thank the European Parliament for being, until the last moment, with the Commission's proposal. I don't understand and I can't understand why we can co-finance 100% small and medium enterprises, why we can co-finance 100% when it comes to jobs for young people, ius guarantees, and we can't finance 100% when it comes to people who lose everything. I have seen in Norcia people who have been in cars for months and months, I have seen burned houses in Madeira, I have seen in Cascia and not only and I will be, as I said, in the islands. It's very easy to sit in a room in Brussels and say I don't agree with 100% co-financing. Where will the Member States get the 5% that the Council has proposed if they do not have it in their budget? That would have meant solidarity. Ask the Member States that voted against the Parliament and Council proposal: what is behind this? We, the European Commission, have proposed 100% co-financing. If there is an earthquake in a member country tomorrow, let the foreign ministries that voted against come and give these co-financings, because we no longer have a budget for such a thing. With regard to the United Kingdom, I would like to make one point again: this cohesion policy exists due to pressure from Britain and Italy, which in ʼ75 closed their mines in Wales and pressured that they would not go to the Council of Italy in ʼ75. How many of the people in Wales in communication know that they now have jobs due to the creation of this ERDF, this Regional Development Fund? How many people in Cardiff know the subway is made from there? As in any Member State, it does not exist nor in the United Kingdom any region, no city that has not benefited from European funds.250 million euros at the University of Manchester, without any European Union flag.I am very sorry, but when it comes to the Friday Agreement, it was neither London, nor Dublin, nor Belfast, it was Brussels that brought these people together and built bridges and built companies and healed wounds that wewe have on the map of this continent.From this point of view, I want to thank you for everything and I assure you that I will be with this cohesion policy until the last moment, because I personally believe that it is the only dimension that keeps us together, the cement that keeps ustogether.This financial solidarity, of which you spoke so beautifully, Mr Novakov.

name: Kerstin WESTPHAL
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! Commissioner, yes, we are by your side. Today in Parliament only cohesion politicians have actually spoken a yes to cohesion policy. But the truth is also: there are others, including within the Commission. You know that as well as I do, and all of my colleagues know that. There are voices that say clearly and very clearly and very loudly: We will no longer need this kind of policy in the future and that there should no longer be the great solidarity within the European Union in the future. I may also take the opportunity to remind you that there is also the Commission's White Paper on the five scenarios. There is also a scenario that speaks of the dismantling of regional funding, of the dismantling of cohesion policy, and in the end perhaps even of abandoning this cohesion policy. And my request - or what I have in mind - is that tomorrow, indeed, a large, large majority votes for this cohesion policy, for our policy - for the people on the ground, so that we can focus on the essentials . Because that's what we want, as all the speakers have said again and again: We need to focus on the essentials. I really want the Commission to come up with a legislative proposal next year, because we need it because we have to work quickly here. And then, dear colleagues, we achieved exactly this goal that we need: We need a strong majority so that we are also able to negotiate. We have to decide on macroeconomic conditionality in a different place and at a different time. Now we need majorities, strong majorities, a large majority so that the European Parliament - and we are the ones who were directly elected - is actually heard.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you all for your interventions. In fact, the debate here shows us once again how important cohesion policy is and I am absolutely convinced that those of us who are here are stronger when it comes to defending cohesion policy, because I too am convinced that there can be no Strong European Union without a strong cohesion policy. And let this be very clear. Of course, it is necessary to do what is necessary to make it more visible, and in this sense it is important to adapt the existing means of communication to technological developments and the diversification of communication channels, because, as you said, there are many stories. successful waiting to be told. It is necessary to involve the beneficiaries in the process of communicating these investments through European funds. At the same time, let us not forget that there are local initiatives to involve citizens in the act of governing, which should be promoted more intensively. We have an example in Gdańsk in Poland and in Cluj-Napoca, where I come from, where the community, or where the authorities have successfully launched concrete initiatives, pilot projects to involve citizens in the local decision-making process, and the contributions they are essential in the budgetary processes on the principle of participation. I am convinced that this initiative must also be implemented at the level of the European institutions, and I therefore want to work closely with the Commission's directorates and national governments at Council level, as well as with social and economic actors, to put this into practice. a coordinated action plan. We are going through a period dominated by anti-system movements - and we all know that - and by expressing growing reservations about the European project, and effective communication, visibility of investments and funding opportunities, as well as and citizen involvement are key ingredients that help strengthen the sense of belonging to the European project.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: rapporteur. - It is very difficult for me, after your fiery words, to defend the agreement reached on assistance provided to countries affected by natural disasters. But I would like to say that a realistic result, when it is a result, is better than an unrealistic desire. We have a result, we have reached a good agreement, we have reached a political agreement that guarantees both the support for the affected regions and the full political support from the political groups in Parliament. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, thank the European Commission for providing us with a tremendous amount of data that helped us to take the decision, and emphasize once again that it is this decision to change the basic legislative package that shows the potential of the policy. for convergence. It shows the potential of this policy to be close to the people, to respond to their problems, to help when needed, but at the same time to ensure the development, growth, jobs and competitiveness of the European economy. This is the meaning of the policy we are discussing today, and the example of the report on legislative change to support countries that have experienced natural disasters is a clear proof that there is a possibility for policy to be flexible, to be effective, to be close to the people. and be understandable to them. So I thank everyone who took part in the debate. Thank you for your words and I hope that we will be able to talk about the real future policy in the very near future.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Thank you too, Mrs. Mihaylova.Let's hope that the call made by our colleague will have an effect and we also thank the Commissioner for the passion with which she supported her point of view.The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, 13 June 2017. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
