text: in writing.- Last year, a series of earthquakes shook central Italy, with serious damage to people, property and cultural heritage.The Commission's proposal to establish a priority axis, dedicated to reconstruction in cases of natural disasters, financed by the European Regional Development Fund is therefore excellent news and a necessary intervention.Although the legislative process has lowered the share of co-financing by the Union from the proposed 100%, to 95% and a ceiling has been placed, equal to 5% of the total allocation of the ERDF per Member State, it is still a priority that theproposal is approved and the funds can be released, as quickly as possible.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. - Cohesion policy is one of the EU's most important policies and an expression of European solidarity. The catching-up of poorer member states will improve the EU's position in global competition, and strengthening social cohesion is the key to continuing European cooperation. However, the implementation of cohesion policy needs to be improved in several respects: Some Member States receive a permanent amount of 2-3% of their national income from cohesion funds without catching up with the old Member States or reducing territorial and social disparities. These problems pose a serious threat to the future of cohesion policy. In any case, when designing post-2020 cohesion policy, these causes must be identified and eliminated. According to a number of studies, one of the main reasons for elite corruption, which also influences the choice of development goals, can only be curbed by a profound reform of management and control mechanisms and an increase in national participation in programs. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO) to prosecute crimes against the EU's financial interests will help to curb corruption with EU funds in the Member States involved in setting up the European Public Prosecutor's Office. However, several countries that have a serious share of the funds are not members of the EPPO. There are legitimate arguments from the Commission and the contributing member states that only member states participating in the EPPO should receive EU support, so the risk of withdrawing EU funds in Hungary and Poland may become a reality.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up. - It is essential that, by 2020, there is the necessary budget for cohesion policy to be able to reduce disparities between regions at European Union level, focusing mainly on the least developed regions. However, I must point out two aspects, which are unacceptable from my point of view, in this report. First, the idea of ​​financing the reception and integration of migrants from the cohesion policy budget does not correspond to the purpose of this policy, given that in the EU, according to statistics, 118.7 million people are at risk of poverty or social exclusion (23 , 7% of the population). Secondly, I believe that it is to Romania's benefit that the gross domestic product (GDP) per capita for each region and the EU average GDP remain the basic indicators for classifying regions and establishing the allocation of European structural and investment funds. In the future, cohesion policy needs to be given more flexibility, but without this flexibility leading to new restrictions or increased administrative burdens. This can be made possible by a minimum regulation at European level, at the level of principles, complemented by national provisions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - Cohesion policy is currently the main source of investment in many Member States and the results are visible. Significant progress has been made thanks to the European Structural Funds in transport, social, but also health, education, urban renewal, municipalities, the environment, but above all the results in supporting new jobs are evident. It is therefore important that cohesion policy is maintained beyond 2020, balancing regional disparities and preventing the depopulation of remote areas. It is therefore important that cohesion policy has an adequate budget, despite the reduction in revenue due to Brexit. Following the experience of the current programming period, it is important that this policy is simplified at all stages - from the announcement of calls, through implementation, to funding and control. It is also important for the use of Eurofunds that the funds can be used more flexibly in the event of unforeseen events, such as natural disasters and unforeseen events. Cohesion policy has many opponents, so it is also important that it is a visible policy, transparent, that the principle of partnership is respected and that the citizens of the region are informed about any investment.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: signed up. - Cohesion policy is considered to be a key investment instrument of the European Union and has a direct impact on all its regions and citizens. Cohesion policy has a major contribution to take into account the scale of Member States' savings and investments. With a budget of 351 billion euros, cohesion policy represents on average 15% of total public investment; moreover, in some Member States it is between 60-80%. However, even if cohesion policy boosts economic growth and increase competitiveness, there are still underdeveloped regions that need priority funding policies, such as the North-East Region of Romania. I support this report because it aims to increase the visibility of structural and investment funds by creating links between cohesion policy instruments and regional policies in order to increase participation and make decisions taken at local level as effective as possible. However, much remains to be done to streamline efforts to reduce disparities between EU regions.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Marco Affronte, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the state of fish stocks and the socio-economic situation of the Mediterranean fisheries sector (2016/2079 (INI)) (A8-0179 / 2017).

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: speaker. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, every year the European Commission prepares the fishing opportunities report for the following year and every year we read data, as regards the Mediterranean, which unfortunately are similar. We see that there are some stocks recovering in some parts of Europe and others that are reaching their maximum sustainable yield, and we continue to read that however in the Mediterranean around 90% of fish stocks are overfished and are therefore well beyond the maximum limit. sustainable yield. I must acknowledge - and I did it personally even a few days ago in New York at the United Nations Conference on Oceans - to Commissioner Vella who managed in the last year and a half to finally bring the focus of attention precisely to the Mediterranean, with a series of initiatives, and we are very happy with this. We started in Catania, where we finally discussed the situation in the Mediterranean between technicians, politicians and scientists. The inter-ministerial meetings continued and finally with the Malta declaration a few months ago and with the MedFish4Ever project, launched by the European Commission. We therefore thought that the European Parliament should also have its position and voice on this very important and heartfelt issue and on this rather complex situation, so we presented this own-initiative report and specifically asked for a open discussion here in plenary, because it is an issue that requires an effort of many people together and of many policies put together. The report was the fruit of very well coordinated work with the shadow rapporteurs and a fairly broad picture emerged. We tried to cover a bit of all the issues, making sure that there was a picture of the situation regarding fishing in the Mediterranean, which is different from any other basin. European both for the type of stock we have, and for the basin we have, which is shared with other non-European third countries, and also for the type of fishermen, given that 80% of Mediterranean fishermen are small fishermen with therefore boats less than 12 meters. We tried to paint a complete picture and then we also tried to give some ideas, proposals and solutions to try to deal with this situation. The points in the report are numerous, I will not remember them all. Whoever is in this House has seen the report and knows it well. I repeat only two or three concepts. We cannot think of a solution for the Mediterranean without involving third countries. For this reason, we really welcome the inter-ministerial meetings held by the European Commission with great satisfaction, because we insist on the same basin, we insist on the same stocks and third countries must work with us to try to make these stocks sustainable. There is no socio-economically sustainable fishery if there are no healthy stocks. So we need to achieve this balance. The situation is now very complicated and that is why the solutions are not unique, but there are several. We have also dealt with somewhat difficult issues such as illegal fishing, which is still very present especially in some states of the Mediterranean basin. We also talked about possible conservation measures, also addressing the issue of quotas, which seems to be a taboo in the Mediterranean, without proposing it and without even forgetting it, but only as something that is there and that could be useful. I look forward to hearing the comments from the Commission and colleagues and I believe that we have done a good job and that it is important that this report is voted on tomorrow in order to have Parliament's voice on this issue.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, dear rapporteur, honourable Members, we have been making tangible progress in our efforts to improve fisheries governance in the Mediterranean. In 2016 we launched the Catania Process and this highlights the urgency in addressing precarious situations for our fisheries. It also made clear the need to join efforts across the region and to set in motion a coherent plan of action for the next ten years.  I think Mr Affronte just said that we cannot think about the solution for the Mediterranean without the third countries, and I think that is really on—spot. To do this, we organised a ministerial conference in March in Valletta and during this the ministers from 13 countries around the Mediterranean signed the Malta MedFish4Ever Declaration. This is a declaration that stresses environmental sustainability, social cohesion and viable economic perspectives. We now have an action plan. This provides a clear set of objectives and targets, against which we can measure our progress. It addresses critical fisheries—related issues including data collection and scientific evaluation, the eco—system—based approaches in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and support for small—scale fisheries. The plan also deals with pollution and transport and their impact on fishing resources. Now, the plan is in place but we must translate our words into concrete actions at three levels: at EU level, at multilateral level and across EU and non—EU countries. At EU level we will continue to implement our Common Fisheries Policy. This will require progress on multiannual plans. The plans, like the small pelagic fisheries in the Adriatic will mark the first test on how genuine our commitments are. We are also working on a plan for demersal fisheries in the western Mediterranean and we are cooperating with the Member States on new national measures, in particular in the Gulf of Lion and the Jabuka/Pomo pit. At a multilateral level we will strive to make further progress in the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean at the plenary next October. This will include the adoption of a regional plan of action to fight illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. It will also involve the establishment of a pilot project of an international inspection scheme in the Straits of Sicily. Last, we must continue to ensure solidarity with non—EU Mediterranean countries. We will do this by supporting them in their structural reforms in fisheries, through the EU Neighbourhood funding instruments.  Our joint political partnership has the power to create a healthy environment, a thriving blue economy and a sustainable fishing sector in the Mediterranean. I am very pleased to see that the report by Mr Marco Affronte is going in that same direction. We would like to congratulate the European Parliament for this initiative. We see that your report is addressing issues that are also important to the Commission: the role of small-scale fishing, measures for third countries, socio-economic aspects, the need for better data and science-based allocation of fishing opportunities and impact of other human activities. The majority of the issues highlighted in your report are directly addressed in the MedFish4Ever Declaration. Both are in the interest of fishermen and citizens.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Mr President, the socio-economic situation of fishing in the Mediterranean, mostly on a small scale, has been deteriorating due to reduced yields, devaluation of fish, restrictions on fishing for certain species, increased fuel costs, which has contributed, among others, to increase fishing effort, with the inevitable increase in risk for fishermen. Measures are required to safeguard small-scale fishing, involving fishermen and their associations and unions in decision-making processes, promoting measures, namely through the channeling of European funds, for the renewal and modernization of fleets, improving working conditions, contributing economic and environmental sustainability, namely by reducing fishing effort. Measures that value work and labor regulation, income, social protection, the recruitment of young people and vocational training, as well as the role of women in fishing, which represent 12% of the labor force in the sector. Measures are required to substantially and objectively reinforce safety with a view to reducing high levels of accidents.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work and his understanding, which has allowed us to reach many agreements. First of all, also, I would like to recall the particular situation that exists in the Mediterranean. More than seventeen thousand marine species inhabit its waters and its coastline is shared by nineteen countries, which makes it necessary for it to continue to receive different treatment from the rest of the marine basins that are under the common fisheries policy, since third countries play a key role in the state of your resources. But it must be recognized that the situation of the populations is far from being the best. This is due to a number of factors, including overfishing, pollution or climate change. This situation forces us to have to take measures, but these have to be backed by tangible and reliable scientific data, something that, unfortunately, does not exist at the moment. Regarding quotas, these must continue to be exceptional measures and respected by all countries. Socio-economic aspects are other factors to take into account, including those related to recreational fishing. Artisanal fishing represents 80% of the fishing fleet and 60% of jobs, so any measure that is valued must take into account its impact, as well as the possible repercussions on many coastal populations dependent on artisanal fishing. since a bad decision can have reversible effects. Therefore, and to achieve a balance between the sustainability of the resources and the socio-economic aspects, the opinion and experience of the fishermen must be taken into account. And finally, I would like to end the need to strengthen cooperation with third countries belonging to the Mediterranean basin. No measure that we propose, either in terms of spatio-temporal fishing restrictions, combats Illegal fishing or inclusion of protected areas may be successful if third countries are excluded.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to my colleague Marco Affronte for the valuable work he has done on this dossier. With its 17,000 species, the Mediterranean is a sea rich in biodiversity. It is therefore important that fisheries management policies have a multi-species and ecosystem approach, based on scientific research and data exchange. However, it is not enough. Local particularities need to be taken into account through the principle of regionalization which remains, in my opinion, the best tool and on which we are working, in the Committee on Fisheries, on a great many dossiers, starting with technical measures. To achieve maximum sustainable yield by 2020, it is necessary to work on several fronts, from safeguarding marine ecosystems to strengthening cooperation with third countries, also to combat illegal fishing, from greater involvement of fishermen in decision-making processes to investment in food education starting from schools, because a conscious consumer no longer eats fish but eats more fish. We must not limit ourselves to reducing the fishing effort, therefore, but we must act on all sectors with transversal policies. The Mediterranean is the sea in which maritime transport is greater than in all the seas of the world and it is therefore on this that we must work, on land urbanization and on waste at sea. In short, we have many arguments to develop in many commissions. If we talk about the Mediterranean, therefore, we cannot ignore artisanal fishing which represents 80% of the fleet. Hundreds of thousands of people are employed, including many women. And then we are not just talking about fishing, but we must also think about who sells the fish, who is a restaurateur, who works in processing, who produces and markets the equipment, and so on. In short, to ensure a sustainable future we must combine the environmental aspects with social and economic ones, otherwise, in a few years, we will be forced to find ourselves here to prevent the extinction of another species, that of the fisherman.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Mr. President, the situation of fish stocks in the Mediterranean is not good, and this has been sponsored by previous policies that have a one-dimensional view of fisheries issues. The turnaround that has already begun to take place when it comes to fisheries policy must be based on scientific research, concrete data and open dialogue with all fishermen and their representatives. Last year, this House overwhelmingly adopted my report on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in fishing-dependent areas. However, the Commission is still ignoring this House's appeal to amend the Mediterranean Regulation, the full implementation of which has significantly damaged Croatia's fishing sector and pushed thousands of families into a difficult situation. We cannot allow fishermen to accuse each other of who is to blame for this situation because we are moving away from a solution. That is why I join Rapporteur Affronte in calling for us to clearly define certain forms of fisheries and, on the basis of scientific research, assess their impact on the state of fish stocks and the environment in general. Only in this way will we be able to devise and implement good policies that will strike a balance between the interests of all fishermen and, of course, the conservation of marine resources. I congratulate my colleague Affronte on a great report which I will, of course, support in the vote.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, I would like first of all to congratulate Mr Affronte on his report. The prerequisite for any action is awareness, and in the Mediterranean it is urgent to become aware of the state of a sea that is in poor health and suffers from the effects of great human pressure. But the Mediterranean is also a sea of ​​diversity with very varied types of fishing, with a predominance of small family businesses and artisanal fishing and where third countries also play an important role in the state of resources. Any initiative to end overexploitation must take into account the uniqueness and diversity of fishing activity in this sea, as well as the fact that the sector has accumulated years of difficulties, due to rising production costs, deterioration of stocks, reduced catches and a steady decline in income. Innovative co-management models adapted to the peculiarities of fishing in each area and that involve administrations, fishermen, the scientific community and other actors in the sustainable management of resources are, without a doubt, a good way to restore balance in the Mediterranean.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, we fully share the need to adopt a multi-species approach when making decisions about the management of the Mediterranean and also the need to define what is understood by artisanal fishing, coastal fishing and small-scale fishing in the European Union. It also seems very appropriate to emphasize that the protection and safeguarding of fishing and marine resources should not fall exclusively on fishermen and women, and here we consider it essential that measures be taken, including the prohibition of those activities of the economy blue that endanger the future of the oceans and fisheries, such as oil and gas extraction, mining, industrial aquaculture, etc. It is urgent and essential to tackle the cleaning and regeneration of the estuaries and prevent tons of garbage and plastics from ending up in the sea every year. Likewise, it is urgent to establish the necessary preventive measures to detect, eradicate and prevent invasive species. Another of the positive aspects of this report is the support for the need for fishing opportunities to be allocated based on objective and transparent criteria, which take into account the social, economic and environmental aspects, and that the distribution is made in a manner that artisanal fishing and small-scale fishing are not discriminated against, both for the level of jobs they generate and for their lesser impact on the environment.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the Mediterranean illustrates perfectly the flaws in the common fisheries policy. It is very different from the Baltic or the North Sea, but the EU says one size fits all. The Mediterranean is not an EU sea and the EU has to buy off non-EU countries which are either massively corrupt, dictatorships or failed states. So agreements are not worth the paper they are written on and do nothing to help ordinary people. This report is full of the usual nonsense, with unrealistic technical measures, unworkable quotas and unworkable minimal sizes of fish. It contains lies and half-truths about the behaviour of non-Western governments. There are no proper controls on subsidies, vested interests or industrial scale fishing. There are massive incentives to simply cheat the system. They are all backed up by platitudes and mother-and-apple-pie sentiments which tell us nothing. In short, everything here does what you should not do – it reinforces the failure of the common agricultural policy (CAP). And while we are on the subject, Britain wants its territorial waters back and we want British fish for British fish and chips.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: That reminds me that Lord Nelson commanded a fleet in the Mediterranean, which were not the territorial waters of Britain, as far as I remember.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Mr President, I want to thank Mr Affronte. The Mediterranean has for many years been the great neglected of the Common Fisheries Policy and I am therefore particularly pleased today that many encouraging initiatives have been undertaken in recent times to address the problems and challenges of this basin. As Verónica Lope said before, the Mediterranean is of extraordinary wealth that the coastal countries have the opportunity to share, but those same countries have the obligation to preserve this wealth. Any measure taken on one side of the Mediterranean is doomed if there are no similar measures on the other side. On the contrary, the measures will be doubly effective if the fishermen feel that they are not discriminated against, if they feel that there is the same playing field for all. A multi-annual approach with technical measures adapted and adopted with the full participation of the sector I believe is the right approach. In my ongoing report on technical measures, I am arguing precisely for real regionalization. In the Mediterranean, the socioeconomic fabric is very fragile, made up mainly of artisanal and traditional fishermen who are also very respectful of the marine environment. These arts and techniques have to be preserved as part of the integrity and cultural heritage of the region and deserve special consideration and incentives. Also recreational fishing, and, in this sense, it is important to make possible fishing activities related to tourism, which, if well regulated, are a very important source of income. The Mediterranean deserves our full attention. Let's not ignore our responsibility.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: - Mr President, I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur, Marco Affronte. Inherent in the definition of sustainable development is the need not to prioritize the three pillars that support it. Therefore, environment, economy and society have to be equated in sync. In Mediterranean fisheries, the environmental pillar has been ignored for too long Without any success for years, technical measures have been tested, such as operating times or mesh sizes. Now is the time to act and protect the environmental pillar that I think is the weakest in this triad. It is absolutely necessary to respect a set of restricted reserve areas and watershed recovery areas and to impose a quota system for the most important fish species in the Mediterranean. At the moment, rabilo is the only marine resource in good condition in the Mediterranean, also the only one with applied quotas. Not urgently applying a quota system will be an enormous responsibility that will guarantee the bankruptcy of fishermen.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Mr Chairman!First of all, I congratulate my colleague Marco Affronte on his report in which he outlined the important issues of fish stocks and the socio-economic impact of the Mediterranean region.Many of these issues are also important for the Baltic Sea.In my opinion, both fish stocks should be protected and fisheries, especially small-scale fishermen, should be encouraged.Therefore, above all, industrial fishing, which is having a degrading effect on sensitive ecosystems and their resources, must be regulated and limited.Small-scale coastal fisheries must be supported and protected using a regional approach.In the context of recreational fishing, I share the rapporteur's opinion - recreational fishing, also in the Baltic Sea, is very important for shipowners, but above all for the local community and deserves effective support.

name: Werner KUHN
text: - Mister President! I would also like to thank Marco Affronte for his report, because it is very important that we also deal with the Mediterranean basin in fisheries. We have the basic regulation, which cannot be applied everywhere to the full extent as we have determined it. For the Mediterranean area it is necessary that we take special care of it. Recovery plans are very important here, and the inclusion of recreational fishing is very important. Everything is protected, everywhere, whether they are seals, whether they are cormorants or whatever. But who actually protects the fisherman? That is always the central question when we go to events like this, where small-scale and artisanal fisheries, cutter and coastal fishermen then ask their questions: What future do we have? Today we have an interesting debate on cohesion policy - a solidarity policy that exists in the European Union, that is, the improvement of business infrastructure. Many things are also possible for fisheries: that the fleet can also be renewed in a certain way via the EMFF, that fishing ports are made more attractive again for tourism too. It is precisely this interaction that naturally plays an enormous role. And when we have tackled these things afterwards, then we simply have to see how we can improve the data situation on the individual stocks, with scientific support, as we do in many other areas, and include the fishermen . That is absolutely the most important question. We cannot make decisions over their heads. Small and artisanal fishing in the Mediterranean sea must have a future!

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I in turn would like to thank colleague Affronte. The Mediterranean is a closed sea with very populated shores, which is subjected to all human pressures. Its biodiversity is threatened, in particular by land and marine pollution which endangers the food chain and therefore the fishery resource. As for overfishing, of course, there are third countries, but there is also the Union. From this point of view, I believe it is time to put in place quotas for all species that scientific advice considers endangered. Today, only bluefin tuna and swordfish benefit from quotas. There is a contradiction between the heart of the common fisheries policy of 2013, focused on maximum sustainable yield, and the failure to draw conclusions for the quota allocation of species in the Mediterranean. Let us underline that the disappearance of fishery resources endangers, on the socio-economic level, the fishing sector in the Mediterranean and, as the resolution indicates, the preservation of fishermen's jobs must also be taken into account, while, I would remind you that Convention 188 concerning fishermen has still not been transposed by the Member States. Beyond declarations of intent, we must find a constant balance between the socio-economic and the environmental aspects, without opposing them, which the rapporteur has done, and I thank him for that.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, fishermen are going through a very serious economic crisis and the European Commission must create measures and mechanisms to protect the income of fishermen. And, in my understanding, this is done in four dimensions: first, in terms of training, both in the arts and in science for the valorization of fish. Second, it also implies a commitment to strengthening the position of fishermen in the value chain. It is unacceptable for fishermen to bring cents home and for large retailers to have large profit margins and for consumers to pay fortunes for the fish they consume. And that implies, and is my third point, the need for us to further strengthen producer organizations. And finally, fourth point, it is necessary to invest in strengthening and creating a salary compensation fund, when there is a ban on fishing. I refer not to the existing, the biological stops, but to the adverse climatic conditions. This is fundamental. I am also referring to environmental catastrophes and contamination by biotoxins. If these measures are applied, we will also have more social justice in fisheries.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, while the topic here is about the fishing sector in the Mediterranean, fishing of course affects all areas and is important to everybody. I come from Ireland and fishing is a very important part of our economy. For that reason, I was pleased to hear Commissioner Moedas refer to the need to engage with stakeholders, and also the need to have up-to-date scientific evidence when we are making allocations, etc. That is a very important point. I think also it was good to hear Commissioner Moedas refer to third countries, because we cannot do this on our own, even if we were perfect within the European Union in fish management, stocks, etc., we could not achieve much, and, especially in relation to climate change, the environment and the sea are very important. The amount of plastic in the sea is an absolute scandal and that is something we really have to work on, both from the point of fishing stocks but also from the point of view of climate change.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: - Mr President, we are in an important debate. It is an initiative report on the Mediterranean Sea, and that has led us to an important reflection. I am from Spain, and one of the seas that we have for our fishing sector is the Mediterranean. But I would like to mention here - some colleague has already referred to this - that the situation in the Mediterranean is not only affected by overexploitation or the fishing sector. The increase in maritime transport also interferes; also the urban situation of the coast and mining overexploitation. In other words, there are many activities, not only fishing, that are involved in the Mediterranean and in the serious situation. I agree that measures must be taken in the Mediterranean, but everything must be taken into account. We have talked about artisanal fishing, but do you know, Mr. Moedas, what the problem is? The problem is that, when applying a differential in artisanal fishing, the Member States do not. And when a quota system has to be applied, they make a standard system and give more to industrial fishing than to artisanal fishing, hence the concern about the quota system. If they have to be applied in the Mediterranean, let them be applied. But you have to take into account the sectors that have greater sustainability and speak, of course, with this sector.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, we are discussing the need to take steps to have fish stocks in the Mediterranean, and, more or less, those who appear to be the scapegoat are the fishermen themselves, while the reality is different. We have a huge pollution in the Mediterranean, due to the fact that we have oil and gas extraction. We have, in general, an infection in the Mediterranean that definitely affects fish stocks. The second is that fishing plays an important role for coastal populations, especially small-scale fishing. Fishermen are currently suffering all over the Mediterranean, especially in Greece with the measures taken by the troika against them. Therefore, what we need is to take measures to protect the income of fishermen, to stop the "tax evasion" policy against them, to have a Fund to support the action of fishermen themselves and of course to support their income, along with investments. , to have a modern fishing fleet.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, fisheries are an important factor for the coastal countries in the survival of their population and, at the same time, an important factor in the country's economy, because the exploitation of the secondary processing sector employs thousands of workers. The same is true in the Mediterranean with the difference that there are too many problems in the Mediterranean. First of all, we have overfishing. Fish stocks are caught at a rate higher than the maximum sustainable yield, with the result that they are gradually depleted. There is also a lot of pollution due to oil and gas extraction and, finally, there is unfair competition from third countries. A typical example of this situation is Greece, which has been flooded with thousands of fish coming from Turkey at very cheap prices, due to the fact that after last year's coup the Turkish pound has been significantly devalued and so there is this unfair competition. To tackle all these problems, the Mediterranean countries must work together, transfer fisheries policy to third countries, control their shores and, finally, prevent NGOs from intervening because what they are doing is serving the interests of the interests of their international donors.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the overall level of surplus fishery resources in the Mediterranean is considered to be double the level of maximum sustainable yield. But the Mediterranean Sea is also subject to other threats, such as pollution, maritime traffic, climate change and the extraction of oil and gas. The Mediterranean must be protected through multi-year management of resources in a sustainable way, with more selective fishing gear, compliance with the minimum size, greater control over illegal fishing activity and, where and if scientific studies require it, even stopping biological. At the same time, however, European fishermen must be guaranteed a decent income. Member States should create a stable income compensation fund precisely to cover fishing freeze periods. The lack of a common regulatory framework for European Union and third country fleets operating in the Mediterranean results in unfair competition to the detriment of our fishermen. Therefore, greater cooperation with third countries bordering the Mediterranean Sea must absolutely be encouraged.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone very much for all your interventions and valuable views. The Mediterranean Sea is part of our shared heritage, part of our cultural heritage and part of our economic heritage, a veritable hub of trade and economic growth. Today, this heritage is at risk, and that is why it is of the utmost importance to protect the region’s ecological and economic wealth. The good news is that it is not too late, and that initiatives such as the MedFish4Ever Declaration or the report that we are debating here today are crucial towards guiding us into the right direction. In order to concretely address these concerns, we should involve everyone: governments, commercial and recreational fishermen, scientists, non-governmental organisations and international and regional organisations, and together we can turn the situation in the Mediterranean around. We look forward to working with all of you, to work with the European Parliament in the implementation of both the Common Fisheries Policy and a MedFish4Ever Declaration in the Mediterranean.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: speaker.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank for the good discussion we had and above all the colleagues who recalled points in the report that I had obviously not had time to mention before.I thank the EMPL committee for strengthening and completing the socio-economic part of the report which, in my first draft, perhaps due to my background, was somewhat weaker than the rest.For the rest, the debate was very intense and very interesting, but there is still a more or less general vision of the whole and also of agreement and we are happy that, as I said at the beginning, this report brings the voice of Parliamenton this very heartfelt issue.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 13 June 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - President! The Affronte report also acknowledges that the level of overfished fishery resources in the Mediterranean is twice or three times the maximum sustainable yield. There is a danger that the Mediterranean will be turned into a desert, even though the sea, which is also the cradle of European culture, is one of the most biodiverse areas in the world with 17,000 species. We must also see that, in addition to overfishing, the Mediterranean is threatened by a number of other factors, such as pollution, changes in coastline and habitats, and oil and gas extraction. It is clear from the above that, in addition to fishing, we must gradually give way to environmentally friendly and modernized marine and freshwater fish farming. For example, a significant part of fishponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 areas. These fish farms do not pose any threat to the natural values ​​of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is due to our closed system of fishponds that the unique wetland associations they have created or preserved are. In the future European fisheries policy, therefore, far more EU funds will have to be spent on environmentally friendly fish farming and aquaculture.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - The Mediterranean Sea is one of the areas with the highest biodiversity in the world, and has an exceptional socio-economic impact on the coastal population and directly contributes to food security. In addition, a large number of local communities depend on small, traditional, artisanal and recreational fishing, which represent great socio-economic and tourist value, and significantly affect employment. However, the Mediterranean also faces serious problems of overfishing, increasing maritime traffic, densely populated coasts and growing pollution that require a common response based on cooperation at all levels, from international to local. I am of the opinion that special attention should be paid to the restoration and maintenance of fish stocks in order to preserve the biodiversity and natural wealth of the Mediterranean Sea. Furthermore, it is necessary to apply ecological, economic and social criteria respecting the precautionary approach in the form of protection of cultural, historical and traditional heritage, socio-economic circumstances, but at the same time to prevent unreported, illegal and irregular fishing. I believe that the effective implementation of the guidelines for sustainable and responsible management of marine resources requires strong comprehensive measures and policies. Therefore, I believe that a sustainable fisheries sector can only be ensured through coordinated action with Mediterranean third countries, taking into account the heterogeneity of marine species and the environment. To this, of course, must be added the collection and exchange of scientific data, and a high level of responsibility and awareness.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Martina Dlabajová and Inés Ayala Sender, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on cost effectiveness of the 7th Research Programme (2015/2318(INI)) (A8—0194/2017).

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: , rapporteur. - I have prepared a report on the cost-effectiveness of the Seventh Framework Program for Research and Innovation in collaboration with my colleague Inés Ayalay Sender, whom I would like to thank, as well as other colleagues, for their many valuable comments and views. Between 2007 and 2013, the Seventh Framework Program managed a total of almost € 55 billion, representing around 3% of total R&D spending in Europe. During the seven-year duration of this program, more than 139,000 research proposals were submitted, from which 25,000 projects of the highest quality were selected and received funding. The main beneficiaries were mainly universities, research and technology organizations and small, medium and large enterprises. I would like to remind you that a total of almost 29,000 organizations from all over Europe took part in the framework program. The experts evaluated this program as successful and I am happy to join their opinion. Like them, I would like to emphasize that top-level scientific activity has been supported at both individual and institutional levels. We have succeeded in connecting small and medium-sized enterprises and in establishing strategic cooperation and developing innovations within industries. I would also like to highlight the support for the mobility of researchers in Europe, the promotion of investment in European research infrastructures, the building of a comprehensive network capable of addressing thematic challenges, thus strengthening the overall European Research Area. These are very specific projects, the contribution of which to society and the economy is not negligible. In the field of medicine, for example, there are new methods for detecting diabetes, cancer or Alzheimer's disease, portable detection tools, etc. In the field of informatics and communications, it is mainly the development of the Internet of Things or artificial intelligence. And I could continue in the field of energy, environmental protection, security or transport. But beware, of course, there is still room for improvement. When evaluating the effectiveness of the program, we found i many weaknesses, such as high administrative burdens, complex legal and financial regulations, too narrow a range of topics and challenges, insufficient emphasis on industry participation or insufficient communication. Both the public consultation with the beneficiaries and a number of audits pointed out that, unfortunately, the main source of error was incorrectly calculated personnel costs and ineligible direct and indirect costs. In this regard, however, I would like to thank the Commission and the Commissioner for the fact that most of these weaknesses have already been addressed in Horizon 2020, and intensive work is being done to eliminate further errors and systematic errors. Support for research and innovation is key to the future development of the European Union. That is why I would very much like to call on the Member States to make a special effort to meet the common goal of investing 3% of the Union's GDP in science, research and innovation. Only in this way will we be able to continue to achieve excellence in research and innovation and thus contribute to the Union's economic growth.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Speaker. - Mr President, I would also like to express my gratitude to my colleague, Mrs Dlabajová, for the good cooperation that we have had in this report, which was precisely intended to anticipate possible problems arising in the evaluation of Horizon 2020 and in the preparation of the Ninth Framework Program for research and development. Because precisely we saw with great concern, from the Committee on Budgetary Control, that there was a recurring error rate and, furthermore, worryingly high, in which no one seemed to have an interest. Most of the years we encountered an error, identified by the Court of Auditors, of more than 5%, which, after many corrections and much negotiation, we were reducing, but also with a very important percentage of operations with errors that - as my colleague has rightly said - they mainly responded to reimbursement problems that the Court of Auditors has identified as one of the biggest problems. Also delays in deadlines and, above all, the feeling of a certain opacity due to redundancies, inconsistencies and some problems in relation to - possible or not - State aid linked to the issue of subsidies, apart from the outsourcing of agencies , which also generates, in that distance, on the other hand, greater problems in management. To say, then, that we have a lot of interest in that before 2020, at last, it is achieved, if so - and the commissioner will tell us today -, if possible, to finish not only the implementation of the previous one - that is, 7 PM - , but also its control, since we are already in full implementation of Horizon 2020 and preparing the new program. Finally, to propose that the management of the General Directorate be more transparent, that the projects and programs, some of them exceptional and very excellent, that we must maintain, sometimes coincide with others of very doubtful efficiency or effectiveness, especially in the column «Innovation» and challenges social, where there is still much to doAnd, finally, to state that there are some important or interesting proposals, such as agreeing with the European regions a pact for science and research that leads to something that we believe is really relevant, and that is that in all budgets ofIn the regions and the Member States of the Union, 3% of the GDP of their budgets was dedicated to research and innovation.We believe that this is where programs like FP7 and Horizon 2020 should try to serve more than a place of placement or profitability for some programs, that some of them are good, but others are more than doubtful.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - First of all, I would like to thank both rapporteurs for a very good report.This report notes that FP7 has been used effectively and points to a number of shortcomings.I assume that the Commission has also learned its lesson and that Horizon 2020 has already taken advantage of the comments that have been made over the past period.In 2015, the largest recipients were researchers in Germany, Great Britain, France, Italy and Spain.Unfortunately, this disproportion turns out to continue during this period, and it would be a big mistake if we could not change this situation.In this matter, I would call on the Commissioner to do everything together with the Member States to make Horizon 2020 better used in terms of geographical distribution.I assume that this is, of course, an effective focus on exclusivity, but it is a pity not to use the potential of more countries.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, to begin with, I would like to congratulate both rapporteurs, Ms Ayala Sender and Ms Dlabajová, for their work and dedication. For me, after all, the 7th Framework Programme (FP7) was sufficiently and successfully implemented. However, there are lessons to be learnt, especially now that we are preparing for the 9th Framework Programme (FP9). We need a much stronger business—science relationship. We should define much more carefully the projects with huge market potential in order to choose the best of them. I would like to see more Nobel Prize winners coming from the EU. I am sure that the achievements we have made with Horizon 2020 and the FP7 are contributing to this. However, there is a weak point: national points of contact. We should put in much more investments and efforts to make them work better in order to make a very good connection with citizens and future beneficiaries.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I agree with the rapporteur, Mrs Dlabaj, who has made it clear that this policy is absolutely crucial for the EU, as is the 3%. If the EU is to succeed in the global market, I firmly believe that it is necessary not only to invest this 3%, but also to reduce administrative and bureaucratic burdens. Unfortunately, I think that accompanies us not only in the Seventh Framework Program for Research and Innovation evaluated here, but also, for example, in cohesion policy. In my opinion, it is necessary not to diminish the importance of Horizon 2020, as was done, for example, by trying the so-called Juncker package. It is important that this policy really remains in the first place, because research and innovation should be at the forefront. Secondly, to be fully transparent and to be as transparent as possible in terms of administrative burdens. To prepare for the ninth framework, we should learn from the fact that we are not leaders in this field, and we should become a leader.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, I think the debate on the cost-effectiveness of the 7th Framework Program for Research is very important and really highlights the problems that have arisen in its implementation. I believe that the issue of transparency is crucial, as well as that there is a huge administrative burden in order for these programs to move forward. Also, the calculation error that reaches 5% I think is a serious issue that should concern us. Beyond that, it is certain that this program should be much more open and much more friendly to small and medium-sized enterprises. I see a tendency for large companies not to want to invest their own funds, just to want to use Horizon 2020 funds to ostensibly grow and invest. I think, beyond that, that there is performance in relation to "Horizon 2020". This program is important to strengthen the competitiveness of the European economy and the 3% of GDP target for research must be implemented.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all let me thank the rapporteurs, Ms Martina Dlabajová and Ms Inés Ayala Sender, for their excellent report on the cost-effectiveness of the 7th research framework programme (FP7). I also take this opportunity to thank all the honourable Members for their continued interest in the field of research and innovation. We all agree on the crucial importance of research and innovation for European job creation, growth, competitiveness and in improving European citizens’ lives.  Your report concludes, and rightly so, that, I quote, ‘the Commission, overall, managed the FP7 cost effectively’ and I very much welcome this conclusion concerning the previous research programme and I take the opportunity to thank publicly my predecessor Máire Geoghegan-Quinn for her tremendous work in her tenure. Your report and all the independent evaluations of FP7 that we have undertaken clearly underline that European research funding is a crucial piece for the future of Europe, which leads to concrete outputs – Mrs Dlabajová just referred to some of those concrete outputs – and for a more competitive economy and better lives for our citizens.  But I also agree with you that the successor of FP7, Horizon 2020, has led to further improvements. We have now one single and simple set of rules that is much more appreciated and more accountable. Your report recognises this, and especially the simplifications that we have been introducing and the second wave of simplification that we will introduce because it is an ongoing process. We are on the right track but we need to do more. We need especially to look at new ideas for funding. This is part of the debate that we will have with the research and innovation community and with this Parliament over the next few years and I look forward to it.  Some of you, I think, raised the questions that are important for the future. Mr Novakov said, how are we going to link better business to science? He said he wants to see more Nobel Prizes. I would just remind you that the European Research Council has produced in ten years six Nobel Prizes, four Fields Medals and five Wolf Prizes. Then I think that when you look at the question of how we are going to work with the Structural Funds, that Mrs Šojdrová said it. We need to work more in widening and look at how we can do better with other countries, how to help them to go up the ladder of excellence.  But let us be honest: Europe still lags behind other places, behind its competitors in some areas, and we are collectively failing to reach the target of 3% of GDP invested in research and development. I really welcome the idea that Ms Inés Ayala Sender put forward of this pact for science with the regions, which is, I think, the way to approach it; how you can actually go region by region in Europe, help them with this pact for science, with investing more, and I think this is something that we should work on together and I count on you.  We cannot therefore rest on our laurels and what we did well. We have to keep working in many areas to ensure that research and innovation framework programmes are as effective as possible, and that research and innovation is supported and encouraged across Europe. This includes having a budget that is sufficient to meet those challenges and again I count on you in this Parliament to help with looking forward to that budget of the future that today is clearly insufficient for what we need for Europe, for jobs and for growth.  Your report also identifies a number of the challenges that we face in implementing a large programme and you know that I take these challenges seriously. A number of them have already been solved and I think Ms Dlabajová recognised that in her speech. Others need to be addressed in the future programme. Your report will provide a good basis for future consideration. Taking as a basis paragraph 13 in your report I will continue to strive for, and I quote, ‘optimal balance between the attractiveness of programmes to participants and the legitimate necessity of accountability and financial control.’  I think this balance is crucial and also answers the point made by Ms Inés Ayala Sender on the error rate, and I think too the point by another honourable Member, that we have to strike this balance between trust and accountability. How can we get this balance right so we have more innovation?  In conclusion, I am delighted that overall you concluded that the FP7 has been managed in a cost-effective manner, which is an encouragement to me and to my colleagues. FP7 has produced very good results and it has been a worthwhile investment of European money. Your report also shows that FP7 was not perfect. Horizon 2020 is in many respects a further improvement, but we should never stop working to improve our programmes.  Ms Dlabajová said several things, but one sticks in my mind: she said that sometimes the topics were too narrow – narrowly defined topics and I think that if you ask me what my dream is for the future, the first is to do what we do well, very well, and not touch it, but that we have to open up in science so we get the best of the best by not defining sometimes those topics as narrowly as you described in your words.  I think that we should not stop working for the benefit of researchers and innovators and for Europe as a whole, and all of you here can be assured that I will continue to work on this. So thank you very much for your attention.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Commissioner, thank you for sharing your dream with us at this late hour. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 13 June 2017.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Constance Le Grip, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on the need for an EU strategy to end and prevent the gender pension gap (2016/2061(INI)) (A8—0197/2017). My understanding is that the rapporteur cannot be present, so Ms Kozłowska—Rajewicz will step in for her.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: deputy rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! The pension gap is the average difference between the pensions of men and women. In the European Union, it is 39%. This is of course an average, because there are countries with a gap of around 45%, and others where it is only 5%. We must realize that today's gap is a consequence of several decades of history of the functioning of women and men in the labor market. Whatever we decide today, we won't affect the present, but we can change the future. That is why in the Constance Le Grip report we talk about preventing a pension gap in the future. The pension gap is a consequence of differences in the course of the lifetime of women and men. Every discontinuation of work, every break for childbirth and childcare, every case of part-time work instead of full-time, delay in promotion, worse negotiated first salary lower the pension amount. The same applies to the wage gap or work in lower-paying sectors and in lower positions. All these features - part-time work, with breaks, with a lower salary - affect women more than men. Therefore, it is women who have a lower pension than men, especially women with children. This is an additional, embarrassing aspect to the story. Due to motherhood, women enter the labor market later than men, due to caring for their parents and grandchildren they leave the labor market earlier, they negotiate their first salary more carefully, they are promoted more slowly. Sometimes they stay outside the labor market for years. It is no accident that the highest employment rate for women in the EU is in the 40-50 age group. It is no coincidence that the employment rate of women over 65 in the EU is 8%. Ladies and gentlemen! The reasons why women earn lower pensions accumulate throughout their working lives. Hence, the pension gap is the best, most aggregate indicator of gender inequality - much more accurate and truer than the wage gap, because it covers a wider spectrum of time and causes as well as effects. Time to start using it. The 40% pension gap between women and men in the world's richest economy based on the values ​​of social justice is embarrassing. No wonder that politicians are outdoing each other in ideas on how to remedy this phenomenon. Unfortunately, not all ideas are good. The main reason for the retirement gap lies in the lower participation of women in the labor market, and shorter work for a lower salary. That is why we have to look for solutions in the labor market. The European Commission's proposal - the work-life balance package - addresses these needs. We write about this in the report. Women must have a chance to earn their pension, but this must not come at the expense of the family. Therefore, it is necessary to compensate for breaks in work resulting from the birth of a child by paying the state pension contributions for the time spent on maternity or parental leave. However, this action must be kept within a rational framework. One must look for an answer to the pension gap also in the pension system, but proposing, for example, a guaranteed retirement pension regardless of work history - as such proposals were made during the preparation of the report - must meet with opposition from politicians seeking effective and lasting solutions focused on the gender gap, and not in pensions as such. The presented report by Constance Le Grip is a balanced, rational proposal in which, according to experts' opinions, we combine the pension gap and potential solutions with the causes of this phenomenon. I appeal to all Members to support this rational line, as maintaining the status quo is unacceptable and the expert opinion makes it clear: the pension system is little responsible for women's low pensions. In order to close the pension gap, it is necessary to enable women on an equitable basis to earn a retirement in accordance with their professional career preparation and potential.We also need to constantly monitor the pension gap, for which we need properly collected data and appropriate indicators to adjust our policies and reduce the pension gap in the future.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the Le Grip report has the enormous merit of giving visibility to the problem of disparity in the pensions of men and women in the European Union. Despite the increase in the participation of women in the labor market in recent decades and the reduction in wage differences between the sexes, gender differences in the labor market and in domestic activities are still large. The fact that, on average, women's pensions in the European Union are 38% lower than those of men, in addition to obviously increasing the risk of poverty for older women, represents an accumulation of gender imbalances and inequalities. throughout active life. In addition to earning lower wages, it is women who see their professional trajectory and, therefore, the continuity of their contributions more often interrupted, either because they are the ones who have more responsibilities in the family or because they are the ones who do more work informal and precarious. Gender equality and non-discrimination are fundamental principles of the European Union. Reducing the gender gap in pensions involves changing the patriarchal model of social protection systems designed seventy years ago and preventing and combating the double exclusion that affects women in active life and, later, in the social protection they have. right, in old age.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - In its report, the EP truly reveals that the reason for the gender pension gap is the interruption of professional careers and fewer years of service due to unpaid work that women and mothers do in their families.We know this from practice.It is statistically proven that the differences increase depending on the number of children.If a woman has 3 or more children, it means up to 20% more difference.In other words, a woman mother who takes care of children invests her time in their upbringing and secures the future of the nation, such a woman is discriminated against and her work is not recognized.The EU cannot dictate to the Member States how to do this, but it is up to them, the Member States, to adjust income levels, to adjust pension schemes, to encourage parents to share and take responsibility.However, the EU's strategy must be a fundamental challenge, supporting motherhood and rewarding the work of caring parents.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would like to begin by saying that the Czech Republic also has quite a lot of white spots in this item, which it has not yet been able to meet, but as far as the European issue is concerned, I would like to say that - perhaps it will sound bold -possible for the pension to be exactly the same.Equality of pensions can definitely not exist economically as a category, it must be a merit system.It should also be appreciated that the woman devoted those years to the upbringing of her offspring, that those years continue to apply to the system that is supposed to maintain social stability.I am convinced that meritocracy should also be assessed in what a woman has done for the company.I agree with everything that my colleagues have said here.Please just realize that women also live longer lives, that is on average 5 years, and that they actually get paid in that system for a longer period of time, which also needs to be assessed.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as emerges from the Le Grip report, there is gender discrimination in Europe which is inherent both in the greater difficulty of women's access to the labor market and in the difference in pay, with a consequent pension gap which exposes women at risk of poverty. Yet equal pay for male and female workers is a fundamental principle of the Union. Ensuring an adequate and sustainable retirement income for all citizens today and in the future is one of the priority European objectives. A European response must therefore be given that addresses the variables from which the gender pension gap originates. We need a strategy aimed at bridging the wage gap and also the provision of measures that facilitate the reconciliation between work and private life and the recognition for contributory purposes of the years of family assistance, a task that normally weighs on women. We must promote and achieve real equality between men and women, in the awareness of the contribution that women, with their work inside and outside the home, bring to the benefit of society as a whole.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - The issue of the gender pay gap appears every year when the European Commission publishes these statistics. However, if women are still discriminated against in terms of pay, it should not surprise us that they also receive an average 40% lower pension in old age. The main reasons are well described in Mrs Le Grip's report. Women work more often than men in low-paid sectors and are also more likely to care for family, children or grandparents. On the one hand, women are still expected to take care of the other, but on the other hand, this care is not appreciated by society. At the same time, women can keep up with the development of their professions after returning from maternity leave, provided they have a sufficient network of quality crèches and nurseries and if they can continue to work flexibly. It is therefore not enough just to make further commitments and strategy papers, but we must make sure that the Member States put these measures into practice as soon as possible. Otherwise, we will continue to meet here for the same debate in the years to come.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the debate on developing a strategy in the European Union to eliminate and largely prevent the pension gap between men and women, I think, highlights the causes that have led to this situation. First of all, for a very long time, decades, there has been a gap in the pay of men and women. Therefore, this directly affects pensions. The second issue is that women are employed in flexible forms of employment, so they do not have very high pension rights. They are also particularly involved in the agricultural sector, yet their work is not recognized. Therefore, important measures must be taken. There is this gap in Greece as well, where pensions are really stuck at the moment. Until 2022, there will be no increase. And will there be a freeze on which pensions? Those that have already been reduced by 60% by troika decisions.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Mr President, it is certainly unfair that, on average, in the European Union, men around the age of 65 and over receive a 38% higher pension than women. At the same time, we need to make it clear that the pension system falls under the social system of the Member States, and that is why it should be fully within their competence. A long-term problem of all Member States, including Slovakia, is the situation of men or women who spend some time outside the work process caring for a family member and are not included in their retirement. I am therefore convinced that both women and men must be free to choose what form of care will suit their child or a dependent member of the household. I consider it the best home care. In Slovakia, however, the evaluation of such domestic work is completely absent. If society does not value such work, unfair pensions will result. But it must be said that the real problem in Slovakia is mainly low pensions overall. How can it be justified that our pensioners have a significantly greater problem of obtaining basic foodstuffs or medicines than men, while in Slovakia the difference in those pensions is the second lowest in the EU on average - only 8%. These are alarmingly low pensions overall, also caused by undeclared work.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Mister President! I believe we have a certain mistake in our thinking here. The point is, of course, that women in general earn around 20% less than men and that of course there is already an imbalance here. But when we talk about the one problem that women also have children and therefore have time off from work, then that is the problem, the central problem throughout Europe, in all 28 Member States - still 28 Member States. In this respect, the point here is that family work is not recognized. If work is paid in the crèche, in kindergarten or even in the children's home, which is done free of charge in the family, then there is an imbalance, and there has to be a balance: that there is a parenting salary that is adjusted to these others that family work is recognized, that reintegration into working life also takes place and that there is family splitting for tax purposes, that children are included in the calculation and that this imbalance does not arise for tax purposes.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, the disparity in the value of pensions between men and women has objective causes. To the systematic discrimination imposed on women throughout their active life, in motherhood, in access to work and in the values ​​of wages, greater vulnerability to precarious work and poverty, are added the consequences of the austerity and right-wing policies that impose a brutal attack on social and labor rights across Europe and Portugal. Contradicting low-wage policies, imposing the principle of equal pay for equal work, valuing collective bargaining, combating precariousness, protecting motherhood, creating public care networks for children and the elderly, the integral defense of public, universal social security and solidarity as the only guarantee of the right to a decent retirement pension are just some urgent and necessary measures to reverse these disparities in the future. Immediately, it is urgent to implement the pension update and to reject any relationship between the increase in average life expectancy and the retirement age.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Mr President, first of all, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Employment Committee, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their collective work, because I consider that it has been very positive and that it would have laid the foundations for designing a strategy against an employment gap. gender in pensions, which today stands at 39% in the European Union. Unfortunately, the rapporteur, referring to a conflict of competences in what were actually political differences with the opinion of the Employment Committee, deleted paragraphs that dealt with the structural causes of labor discrimination, which multiplied its effects when the age of retirement. And we already see how important it is for the rapporteur to combat the gender gap when she preferred today to be at a political event for her party rather than being here defending her report in this House. She continued to refer to the amendments that we proposed from the Employment Commission to resolve these paragraphs that have been eliminated; They refer to the dignity of work and wages in the most precarious and feminized sectors, the strengthening of public pension systems, and the objectives to combat discrimination against women in the workplace.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Mr President, I would like to draw your attention here today to the disparity in pensions that also exists in agrarian activity, especially for those farmers who carry out their activity in the context of family farming.Usually, they start their contributions later and then, of course, they have fewer years of social contribution.In many cases, they remain invisible throughout their working life, thus leading to situations of heavy dependence on their husbands at an advanced age and also to many situations of poverty.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of my colleague Věra Jourová, let me thank everyone here for the work in this House on this very important topic.  Women account for almost two-thirds of pensioners in the EU, and they receive pensions which are, on average, 38% lower than men. They make up the bulk of the pensioners who have small pensions. As a result, many women experience retirement under financial constraints and with an increased loss of independence, as some of you described. Older women are also far more likely than men to live alone and with limiting disabilities. This makes their lower pensions even less adequate. Simply put, older women in the EU are at higher risk of poverty and social exclusion then older men.  The Commission is glad to see that the European Parliament has taken up this major issue, and I would like to thank Ms Le Grip and Ms Kozłowska—Rajewicz for their hard work on this report. It rightly puts emphasis on how to improve women’s ability to build up pension entitlements. But, unfortunately, the gender gap in pensions is likely to persist as long as women continue to earn less and are more likely to interrupt their careers and to work part—time. These factors further reinforce the gap. We need decisive action to increase women’s participation on the labour market. We need to ensure that they are no longer obliged to choose between their family and their professional career. We also want to give fathers more opportunities to take on more family responsibilities. This is precisely the aim of the initiative to support work-life balance for parents and carers which the Commission adopted in April 2017. This package of legislative and non-legislative actions is one of the concrete initiatives, putting the principles of the pillar of social rights into action.  In addition, the Commission is committed to taking action against the root causes of the gender pay gap. Discrimination on the grounds of gender is still prevalent at work, so strong monitoring and enforcement of existing rights is more necessary than ever. We will continue to support stakeholders in their effort to break the glass ceiling, to combat segregation on the labour market, to improve women’s access to high—earning professions and to ensure that skills, efforts and responsibilities are recognised in all sectors. Action is needed to close gaps on the labour market, but it is equally important to guarantee decent pensions to current pensioners. We need to take into account the situation of older women who have already reached, or are nearing, retirement age.  I hear and share your concerns that recent pension reforms may actually exacerbate inequalities. We will be vigilant and further investigate the effect of a shift towards a multi-pillar system. For instance, in the framework of the 2018 Pension Adequacy Report, we will continue to draw attention to gender gaps in our cooperation with the Member States on pensions.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Commissioner, thank you for your words and for being with us here this evening. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 14 June 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. Unfortunately, the gap between women's and men's pensions in the EU remains bridged. It is very sad that Cyprus is recording one of the highest performance in terms of the difference in pensions between the two sexes. We support with all our might any effort to achieve real equality between women and men, but also to prevent poverty and the vulnerable situation in which women receiving low pensions are at risk. We therefore consider it necessary to have a comprehensive and generalized strategy for addressing the gender pay gap.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up. - Recent studies at European level show that over the last five years the gender pay gap has continued to widen in more than half of the Member States. The financial crisis of recent years has also had a negative impact on the incomes of many women, and in many Member States, between 11 and 36% of women do not receive any kind of pension, mainly due to certain phenomena. discrimination, segregation and interruption of the career path. In these circumstances, it is important that Member States, in collaboration with the European Executive, make efforts to combine pension policies with appropriate employment and active aging policies, in order to reduce gender pay and pension disparities by encouraging cooperation. and exchanges of good practice between Member States, in order to avoid discrimination in the training and career advancement of women. I also support the rapporteur's proposal on the need for Member States to implement the Commission's recommendations on wage transparency, job descriptions and classification of gender-neutral jobs, reversing the burden of proof when it comes to challenging gender discrimination in the workplace.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - The retirement pension has become the main source of income for 25% of EU citizens. This number will double by 2060 due to the aging of the population. The stake is therefore essential, in particular to fight against poverty and social exclusion of our elders. While the organization of pension systems is an exclusive competence of the Member States, the EU has a supporting competence (Article 153 TFEU). Unfortunately, we note that there is an inequality between men and women: within the EU, this gap was, in 2012, 38% for those over 65. The causes are the high rate of low paid women, working hours and part-time working, often linked to maternity.
