We must continue to fight against this discrimination and guarantee equal pay for equal work and equivalent seniority. The introduction of credit for retirement points is a possible axis. On the other hand, we oppose the minimum public pension (which borders on the European minimum wage) as well as the increase in the minimum number of years of contributions. Finally, we are against the individualization of pension rights which calls into question the unity of the family home.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: signed up.- Today, in the context of increasing life expectancy, there is a need more than ever to guarantee real equality between women and men, but also to prevent situations of poverty and vulnerability, which are more likely to affect women with low pensions.The pay gap is clearly the result of a series of lifelong inequalities in women's professional careers, and the Union must actively contribute to eliminating them.Unfortunately, in 2017, there are still gender pay gaps in the EU, amounting to 16.3% in 2014, mainly due to discrimination, segregation, but also discrimination.interruption of the professional path.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - Inequalities in the pensions of men and women in many Member States of the Union give cause for extreme concern. As an integral part of a comprehensive strategy in the fight for gender equality in all spheres of life, the harmonization of pension systems is extremely important for all members of society who are at greater risk of poverty due to the systematic restriction of their rights. The average pre-tax income gap received as a pension in 2014 was 39.4% in the age group of 65 and over, and we have seen a dramatic increase in these figures in more than half of the Member States in the last five years. Lower women's pensions are a direct consequence of the gender pay gap, which, despite Union equality legislation, is still widespread in the Member States of the European Union. I support this Legislative Proposal because of the consistent and necessary need to change the differences in the pensions of men and women. The European Union cannot allow systematic discrimination against women. Pensions are the main source of income for every fourth EU citizen. The dramatic situation of pensioners will worsen if we do not first raise public awareness of the existing shortcomings and then take all necessary measures to remove the existing barriers.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - Gender pension gaps remain one of the major challenges when it comes to forms of inequality between women and men. In 2012, the gender pay gap was as high as 38% in the age group of 65 and over, which is unacceptable. It is high time that Member States start adopting appropriate policies that will adequately address this problem. The EU aims to achieve real equality between women and men, as well as to prevent poverty and vulnerability, which most often affects women with lower pension benefits. Many countries, including Slovenia, use the pay as you go system when it comes to the pension system. This is a system where young people pay for the elderly. Given that the situation between young people and the elderly is changing significantly in favor of the elderly, which is of course welcome, as we live longer, especially the countries that use this system will have to consider upgrading it. At this point, I think it is important that the creation of social systems is in the domain of each individual country, but given the problem I see, I believe that the Union could also be more active, especially when it comes to the sustainability of pension systems. At the end of the day, of course, it is the responsibility of the Member States to introduce an integrated approach, both to pension systems and to tackling the problem of aging and the growing incidence of poverty among pensioners.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I strongly support the adoption of the report on the need for an EU strategy to close and prevent the gender pension gap. The report opens up the issue of pension disparities in a transparent and reasoned manner and calls on the Commission, in close cooperation with the Member States, to develop a strategy to close these disparities. Statistics clearly show that the differences are the result of discriminatory treatment of women in employment and unsatisfactory definitions of individual types of work in obtaining a pension period and a pension base. The call for a strategy aimed at reducing and eliminating disparities is therefore more than justified. At the same time, I must reiterate the need to adopt a European Union strategy in response to demographic change in Europe, and I reiterate my call on the European Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, to formulate and adopt it. We need a document that highlights all aspects of an aging society in Europe and provides guidance on how to respond to and adapt to them. The message of all of us in the European Parliament who strive for a dignified life for older people in society is clear, and this report also points this out: a decent pension is essential to combating old-age poverty, and we must not accept any form of discrimination.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Amjad Bashir, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on statelessness in South and South—East Asia (2016/2220(INI)) (A8-0182/2017).

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am honoured to address today’s plenary as the rapporteur for the report on Statelessness in South and South East Asia. For the overwhelming majority of colleagues in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, it was felt that this report was worth embracing – from the very first draft through to the final text – unequivocally, and irrespective of political affiliation, because we are deeply appalled at the UN Refugee Agency’s estimates that 135 million children under the age of five, across the South and South East Asia region, have not had their births registered and are at risk of becoming stateless. We are mindful that being a Rohingya, for instance, (the largest stateless ethnic group in the world) equals living literally in the shadows, as a non—person in the eyes of the authorities, unable to stay in, unable to move out, stripped of property rights and denied access to health, education and the right to start a business.  As a proud British Conservative, I uphold a rich tradition that champions the cause for the small state, both in number and regulatory functions. The raison d’être of the state, anywhere in the world, is to defend, protect and enforce the rule of law so that each and every individual is genuinely free. People of all ethnic, religious and cultural backgrounds must have their unalienable rights protected, down to the last individual, because the smallest minority is the individual.  My thinking is influenced by Aristotle’s emphasis on the individual. Our prosperity in Europe is the result of the consciousness that no one should be above the law. It was the Magna Carta, in the early 13th Century, and the contributions of Thomas Hobbes and John Locke on the social contract, that paved the way forward. As in 18th Century Prussia, those at the mercy of the Myanmar authorities must be able to stand up and say that there are judges in Berlin. The Myanmar authorities’ failure to fulfil these essential state functions must spur the international community to act. We must recognise the progress made in Indonesia, Cambodia and Vietnam. However, there are still millions who are stateless and persecuted every day because of it. Enhanced political and economic relations with Europe go in tandem with individual freedoms and the rule of law. These are the messages that Myanmar, and any other country in this region and the world, must be reminded of. I am proud of this House, honourable colleagues, because we seized this noble opportunity to focus across the political spectrum on the absolute essentials of life, liberty and the right to happiness. Tomorrow’s vote will provide hope to those who are suffering and ensure that promoting citizenship is a priority for the EU.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I wanted to speak in support of Mr Bashir's report.A few months ago, we discussed the very difficult situation of the Rohingya here in plenary on human rights issues, and how the country there, Myanmar, once Burma, is suppressing them.And how about the fact that these people do not have the citizenship of their country, how they are bullied, persecuted on that basis, and I am not afraid to say that there are even certain genocidal practices.The Rohingya are not the only ethnic group in Southeast Asia, there are more of those groups, and it is good that there is general material today that makes it clear that we want these countries in Asia to respect the UN conventions of the early 1960s, which clearly say that man hasthe right to citizenship, has the right to the citizenship of the country where he is born, unless he acquires another citizenship.And we should enforce this principle and want it to be applied in international relations.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, I agree with the report's findings, which call for the reduction and eradication of statelessness to be desirable and highlight the unacceptable situation of stateless people in Burma and Bangladesh. I support the approach that each situation is different, but different historical reasons cannot provide a basis for the deliberate maintenance of statelessness by individual states. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the fact that hundreds of thousands of people in the European Union still live stateless and have not fled. No one disputes the repression of the Baltic nations by the Soviet Union, but it really should go beyond the thinking of this era. How can we criticize distant countries like Burma or Bangladesh if we, developed Europeans, follow the same policy? This practice is discrimination based on nationality in the European Union, but we are not talking about it. We act as if a family is unaware of an unpleasant event to see if it resolves on its own. We cannot turn our heads around our own problems while loudly whipping others in Bangladesh or Myanmar.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: - Mister President! Thank you for giving me the floor. As a member of a minority, I can only empathize with how difficult it must be for a group when it is denied citizenship itself. I think it is right that we are also talking about the Rohingya situation in this context. But I also have to say that a few weeks ago I had the chance to be in Myanmar for several days and to meet both Ms. San Suu Kyi and the commission on the Rakhine State led by Kofi Annan. I think it would have been right if, in this resolution, we had at least referred to the working group led by Kofi Annan and had pointed out that Mrs San Suu Kyi is currently working very hard to improve the situation, despite all the difficulties that exist Area there. I think we owed that to the Nobel Peace Prize laureate. I think it would be right if we not only condemn, but also effectively encourage the state of Myanmar to finally get ahead on this matter and find a good solution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, we have discussed the Rohingya drama several times in this Chamber and we have had the opportunity to denounce Myanmar's unacceptable and illegal treatment of this minority, these people, who are mainly religious but also ethnic reasons, are persecuted and have no luck and no rights in Myanmar. But I see that there are also problems with the thousands of Bihari, who are being treated similarly by Bangladesh. We are now watching problems all over Asia. The fact that births are not recorded and we have 136 million children who do not have birth certificates, really proves the dire situation we are in. However, I am referring to point 10 of the report which points out that the right to citizenship is the exclusive responsibility of each state and this must be respected.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Mister President! Statelessness, 135 million children - that's a problem that speaks for itself. No property rights, no health care. But we also have another form of statelessness, and that stems from our colonial history. The island of New Guinea is divided between Papua New Guinea and West Papua. West Papua belonged to the colonial territory of the Dutch, and when it came to independence from Indonesia, Indonesia was recommended to add this half of the island to Papua New Guinea. In the meantime, 54% of the population has been relocated, transferred to the islands, become homeless, and stateless in this form. There is only 46% of the original population left, who have high levels of languages ​​and tribes, making it incredibly difficult to clean up again. I think that this is a task that we as former colonial powers have to clean up again and to say: people, this state of affairs cannot be maintained like this.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, one of the basic human rights is the right of every person to have the citizenship of the country in which he was born. Unfortunately, this principle is not applied by all countries of the world. There are some countries in South Asia and Southeast Asia, mainly Myanmar and Bangladesh, which for various reasons, which serve unacceptable purposes, do not grant citizenship to their nationals. As a result, these unfortunate people can neither find a job, nor get married to start a family, nor have care, and are eventually forced to leave their country against their will. Many of them come as illegal immigrants, mainly to European Union countries, thus exacerbating the already existing problem of illegal immigration. If the European Union wants to prove that it is indeed defending human rights, it must press these countries to obey international law, grant citizenship to their nationals and thus serve, in general, humanitarian interests.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Bashir on his report. This topic is of great importance for the European Union and for me personally, and I am glad to be here today with you. The European Union addresses statelessness in different aspects of its external policies, including in our political relationships and development cooperation programmes, as well as in the enlargement process. Through our humanitarian assistance we support the lives of stateless people: I have seen this myself on the ground very recently. We encourage third countries to ratify the 1954 Convention Relating to the Status of Stateless Persons and the 1961 Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness. We urge partner governments to take measures to address situations of statelessness, including by granting citizenship to stateless persons, and we call on them to ensure that these people have access to public services, including health and education. Stateless persons are vulnerable to arbitrary treatment and crimes like human trafficking. Where whole communities are affected we can witness poverty and marginalisation and, as a consequence, significant humanitarian and development needs. The marginalisation of such people can create tensions in society. It can lead to radicalisation and this is extremely dangerous. It can lead to instability at both national and international level. Also, in extreme cases, it can lead to conflict and displacement. Statelessness is an issue the EU addresses in a series of instruments and policies: first, the EU Action Plan for Human Rights and Democracy; second, the EU Human Rights Country Strategies for a number of countries; and third, the New European Consensus on Development – to name a few. The EU has funded a range of development and humanitarian assistance programmes in the area of statelessness. These programmes aim to raise awareness of the issue, assist stateless persons and support governments in addressing the problem. Let me give you some concrete examples of our action in South and South East Asia. Maybe you know that last month I visited Myanmar. I met with the authorities and travelled to the troubled Northern Rakhine State to meet with Rohingya representatives and assess the humanitarian situation on the ground. This was the first ever visit by an EU Commissioner to that region and the first high-level international visit in general since the violent incidents of October 2016. I announced new humanitarian assistance for the current year 2017, and I stressed the need for full humanitarian access. I also asked for unrestricted access to health, education and other services for the Rohingya minority, the largest stateless group in the world. What I stressed to all my Myanmar interlocutors is that only steps towards community reconciliation can bring peace and stability. Reconciliation is not an easy process – I know this from personal experience as a Cypriot – but it is the only way forward. The situation in Rakhine State was the focus of the meetings that State Counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi had with President Tusk, High Representative Mogherini and me on 2 May in Brussels, just before my visit to the country. The plight of the Rohingya has been prominently discussed at human rights dialogues with Myanmar which the EU Special Representative for Human Rights has held since 2014.  The EU strategy with Myanmar of 2016 also calls on the Government of Myanmar to address the challenges of Rakhine State, including the status of the Rohingya. This requires inclusive development in all areas and a political process, including resolving citizenship for stateless persons in a non-discriminatory manner through a transparent, voluntary and accessible procedure. In March 2017, the current year, just three months ago, the EU continued to table a resolution on the human rights situation in Myanmar in the EU Human Rights Council, and it was adopted without vote. The EU is a major donor to humanitarian assistance and development cooperation programmes in Rakhine State. Since 2010, more than EUR 76.5 million of humanitarian aid has been allocated to vulnerable people in the region. Our current development assistance in Rakhine State amounts to EUR 25 million, benefitting all communities. The Union also provides long-standing and significant support to the Rohingya in the refugee camps in Bangladesh, with EUR 6.3 million in humanitarian aid allocated in 2016 and EUR 6 million as the EU’s contribution to UNHCR for 2014-2017. Their situation is regularly discussed in political dialogues with the Government of Bangladesh. Birth registration was raised at the most recent human rights dialogue with the country, in December 2016, and also featured in the related EU statement which urged Bangladesh to provide assistance and protection and not to turn the Rohingya back to Myanmar. In 2008, the Supreme Court ended the statelessness of the Bihari in Bangladesh. The European Union aims to reduce inequality and exclusion of all marginalised groups in Bangladesh, through its wider public diplomacy and development cooperation efforts. In Nepal, the European Union, together with other international partners, is exploring sustainable solutions for the Bhutanese refugees. We are working with UNHCR on an exit strategy for them, while providing protection and multi-sectoral assistance.  I would like to thank the House for your attention, your suggestions and your observations, and please remain assured that the European Union remains committed to working with partner countries and other international partners towards eliminating statelessness.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 13 June 2017.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163). May I say two things. First of all, the list is rather long so I will strictly apply the time of one minute. Secondly, I know that somebody has today proposed the possibility of speaking in his/her language, beyond the scope of the official languages of the European Union for which we are equipped here today. That is not possible and we will continue in the official languages of the European Union.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, I would like to draw attention here to the case of the Czech war journalist Radan Sprongl detained at Bangkok airport before leaving for Iraq.The man faces charges of illicit possession of war material and faces up to five years in prison simply for carrying protective equipment, which serves as a vital protection for journalists in war zones.Moreover, this is not the first case of its kind.Two journalists from the European Union, who have already been released, have recently been arrested for the same reason.The Thai negotiations should worry the European Union.European diplomacy must show that it does not like this approach, and it should help journalists to get back to countries where they can continue to play an important role.

name: Andor DELI
text: - Mr President, according to a recent analysis, some 15,000 haulier jobs in Hungary could be jeopardized by restrictions imposed by some Western European Member States. The last such measure is the tightening introduced by Germany on 25 May, which states that a 45-hour rest period cannot be spent in the cab of a vehicle. Meanwhile, the infrastructural conditions for this are not provided, as there is not enough sheltered parking and accommodation to meet the increased needs. Cargo, vehicle and fuel are also at risk, but even a vehicle left unattended can serve as a potential terrorist attack, and the issue of liability is unclear. Without creating the preconditions, all this will not serve safety and improve the conditions for drivers, but will give the impression of a simple protectionist measure. I therefore call on the Member States concerned to review these measures and not penalize foreign carriers until the preconditions for compliance have been established.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - (The speaker intervenes in Catalan.)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Gambús, I am terribly sorry but there was no English interpretation. I will give you the opportunity to start once again so that colleagues can benefit from the English interpretation. Can we try it? Could you start again? I apologise once again.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET

name: Pavel TELIČKA

President Tajani refused that option, so you can speak Spanish or any other official language, but we do not have interpretation from Catalan, so I will have to ask you to refrain from using that language.

text: Mr Gambús, just to explain, I was initially informed that President Tajani had refused that possibility, but this was then corrected. I apologise, as I did not receive precise information.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Mr President, while the responsible EU leaders have been saying that we can only find a solution to the migration crisis together - they have been unable to deal with the crisis for years, and they are the main obstacles to a real solution. In contrast to Brussels, Hungary and its allies offer a real alternative to the EU's flawed immigration policy - yet they face rejection, condemnation and threats. In his resolution condemning Hungary at a time of serial and brutal acts of terrorism that threaten our entire European culture and identity, our Parliament, in the person of Ahmed H., is embarrassing politicians and blackmailing our country with possible sanctions. The responsibility for the current crisis lies not with Hungary, but with the Union's migration policy. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Mr President, we have been talking a lot lately about the need to respect democratic principles in the European Union, including the protection of minorities. Yes, I am talking about the 50 million EU citizens who identify themselves as belonging to a minority and who have now taken advantage of the European Citizens' Initiative to start collecting one million signatures. We are asking the European Commission, namely Mr Frans Timmermans, to make the most important Council of Europe minority protection documents binding in the EU's internal legal order. The most important of these, the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages, which is celebrating its 25th birthday. Indeed, the protection of the rights of indigenous minorities is unsatisfactory, for example, in Slovakia, of which I am a citizen. There is a lack of a positive attitude, the application of the Charter is unsatisfactory. Nothing proves this better than the fact that I could have made this speech here in the European Parliament in my mother tongue, and I could have done the same in my country 30 years ago, under the communist dictatorship. But today, in Slovakia, an EU Member State, I have no right to do so, which is unfortunately a step backwards.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, the United Nations Conference on Oceans took place last week in New York, in which I had the honor of participating as head of the European Parliament delegation. It was a real turning point in the recognition that the ocean, our ocean, is crucial for the future and for humanity in all its diversity. This Conference aimed to support the creation of conditions for the implementation of the 14th UN Sustainable Development Goal, dedicated to the sustainability of the Oceans. The European Parliament delegation participated in multiple bilateral meetings with representatives of the World Bank, the United Nations Environment Program, the Convention on Biological Diversity and with the delegations of the USA, China and Brazil, in the framework of improving coordination and cooperation between international organizations and the creation of partnerships in the field of the oceans. 193 UN member states approved by acclamation the declaration “Our Ocean, Our Future: Call for Action”, which commits all countries to work for the sustainability of the oceans. Dear Colleagues, the European Union has made important types of commitments in political recognition of the importance of conserving marine resources and ecosystems. There is now an urgent task to act in defense of the oceans and to implement a new and ambitious International Ocean Governance.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, let me commemorate the symbolic anniversary.Seventy years ago, in June 1947, the so-called Marshall Plan for the Economic Recovery of Postwar Europe was officially announced.Why is it good to remember this event?It was an unprecedented act of solidarity on the part of the United States towards a war-torn Europe.The Marshall Plan was a prominent element of strong transatlantic relations during the Cold War.To manage this plan, the so-called Organization for European Economic Cooperation was established, from which the OECD later evolved.The rejection of the Marshall Plan by the future countries of the Eastern bloc was a symbolic opening of the Iron Curtain.There are many interesting lessons for the present associated with the Marshall Plan, ranging from the importance of US-Europe relations to the importance of European cooperation.This gesture of exceptional solidarity, which has paid off for both continents, needs to be recalled.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, our European societies, which profess so much freedom as a key value of a democratic state governed by the rule of law, are threatened by new, hitherto unknown dangers. Terrorists, who have no demands, no fixed structure, whose only ideology is the greatest possible evil and ruin, are deliberately destroying the lives of defenseless victims, using the means we have hitherto considered relatively common consumer goods. There is nothing easier than taking a car and knocking defenseless victims to the ground like skittles. So far, this has not happened to such an extent. We are therefore facing a completely non-standard threat and we should consider whether the tools we use against this threat are sufficient. I consider it important that we also pay more attention to the households in which radicalized young people - whether Islamic fanatics or Breivik fanatics - live. We must also ask for their share of co-responsibility, so that they are obliged to draw attention to indications that, in principle, only they can perceive as coexistents who clearly confirm the radicalization of these people. Let us also demand responsibility from people who live in such households.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: - Mr. President, last week in our country we experienced the liquidation of a century-old bank such as Banco Popular. Undoubtedly, this operation has been carried out without the use of public money, but we should not congratulate ourselves either, given that it has generated problems of financial instability and, in addition, it has destroyed the savings of thousands of small investors with little information. It is worth asking, therefore, if there was any alternative option to that liquidation, if an orderly sale of Banco Popular was possible. In my opinion, yes. Without a doubt, the managers of Banco Popular have suffered from irresponsibility. There have been bad practices in the commercialization of convertible capital and in its last capital increase, but we cannot ignore the alarmist statements of the president of the Single Resolution Mechanism, Elke König, in an interview on May 23. There are those who place in this interview the beginning of the end of Banco Popular. That is why I have asked for Elke König to appear in this House, so that she can explain her actions.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: - Mr President, at the end of this month, the European Commission will announce the specifications that will have to be fulfilled by the states that will enter the race for the relocation of the European Medicines Agency. In this way, I call on European Commission officials to take into account an older European Commission resolution as a recommendation when drawing up eligibility criteria, which states that when setting up newly established European agencies on the national territory, priority must be given to states that they have no agency. This recommendation must also be valid in the case of relocations of European agencies, a phenomenon generated by Brexit and which did not exist at the time of issuing the recommendation in 2011. Another thing that should be taken into account by the representatives of the European Commission when drawing up the criteria is the degree of terrorist danger. Fortunately, Romania has the advantage of being one of the few European countries where the terrorist danger is non-existent. If we win this race, Romania would be the first state in Eastern Europe to host an institution of major importance to the European Union, which would be an important political signal in the effort to demonstrate the unity of the European Union.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!Three weeks ago, our Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality was on a mission in Poland where it held meetings with numerous feminist organizations.The leadership of the commission, however, did not want to meet the requesting women's organizations committed to the right to life and the rights of the family.The management made it impossible for the members of the commission to get acquainted with the point of view of this part of Polish public opinion and from interested women's organizations for public discussion with their opponents.This exclusion is unfortunately the worst evidence of discrimination against women's groups that defend life and family, as well as discrimination against the Members of our Parliament who are interested in their position.I am counting on a reaction from the leadership of the European Parliament on this.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr Chairman! After the introduction of the preparation with the sonorous name ellaOne - prescription in Poland - protests of opponents of conceived life began, however, many doctors still wonder on what basis it was allowed to sell the untested preparation, ulipristal acetate, to children without a prescription, while in the product description There is an annotation that the contraceptive, depending on the cycle, including early abortion, is not intended for children and adolescents, and its safety has been determined only in women over 18 years of age and in a limited number of girls, which is a scandal and should cause concern. The thirty milligram dose of ulipristal acetate, which can be doubled as indicated, is much greater than that administered in the treatment of uterine fibroids, where endometrial control is indicated due to the development of histopathological changes. I could cite other side effects, but it would take a few minutes.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Mr President, I will quote today’s article in the biggest Estonian newspaper: ‘every house has its own rules and it is up to the owner to decide how strangers can behave. In one family, they do not like it if you use the wrong fork, in another it is possible to crap in the corner.’ What kind of family is Estonia? We respect newcomers and do not forbid them to follow their customs but they are not allowed to walk in dirty boots on the clean carpet. Therefore, the discussion about language in kindergartens is ridiculous. There is no option about Estonian. Those who want to bring up their child in another language can do it at their own expense and at their own risk. This is said about 32 % of Russian-speaking Estonians, taxpayers who have lived in my country for more than three generations. About children whose mother tongue is compared with ‘crap in the corner’.  Here in this House we discuss the problems of human rights and linguistic diversity in the world, but please, let us pay attention to the EU where we still have a number of unresolved minority issues and where, in order to justify xenophobia, we still speak in terms of owners and the guest in our common house.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: - Speaker speaks in Frisian.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I understood nearly all of it.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, I want to join tonight in the declaration of the 25th anniversary of the promulgation of the European Charter for Minorized or Regional Languages, thinking, as they say in my mother tongue, (the speaker spoke in Basque). Because article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights prohibits all discrimination and expressly includes, among many others, that exercised by reason of language or belonging to a national minority. Those who do not suffer this discrimination think that exercising it is a venial sin, but only because it is common to consider that (the speaker speaks in Basque), while at least 50 million Europeans feel that our fundamental rights are being violated. Because in the Union our mother tongues are outlawed. (The speaker spoke in Basque.) In Europe and more nations than States and more languages ​​than the official languages ​​of the Member States. However, the speakers of the latter are not protected by the Treaties. Daily experience proves it. A space of democracy and freedom will never be such if (the speaker intervenes in Basque).

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: - (The speaker intervenes in Catalan.)

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: - Mr President, the problem is not that here they deny interpretation to languages such as Basque.The real problem is that the same thing still happens in my country, where the Spanish and French states grant different linguistic rights to Basque society and sometimes even deny them.But we are not going to give up here either, and I am going to speak in Basque.(The speaker intervenes in Basque.)

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, táim chun labhairt anocht ar an gCairt Eorpach um Theangacha Réigiúnacha nó Mionlaigh agus sinn ag ceiliúradh 25 bliana ó glacadh leis. Is conradh é atá chun cosaint a thabhairt do chainteoirí teangacha neamhfhorleathana. Is buncheist bheo í teanga san Eoraip mar atá sí sa bhaile; agus cheana féin tá an iomarca modhanna leithcheala á ndéanamh agus níl aon amhras ach go bhfuil cearta teanga daoine á sárú i gcás gach teanga réigiúnach dúchasach nó mionlach san Eoraip. Ní teanga mhionlach mo theanga, is í an Ghaeilge mo phríomhtheanga agus ba mhaith liom go dtabharfaí an t-aitheantas iomlán sin di. Tá sé tábhachtach go seasfaimid mar fheisirí go láidir ar son ceart teanga agus ar son ceart daonna, agus ba mhaith liom ardmholadh a thabhairt do gach feisire eile a labhrann anseo anocht faoin ECRML, fiú nuair nach raibh ateangaireacht ar fáil—rud atá scannalach. Tá ár dteangacha tábhachtach, ní amháin dár bhféiniúlacht ach dár bhféinmhuinín, dár n-éiceolaíocht, dár gcultúr agus níos mó. A chairde, mar a dúirt mé cheana féin, nuair a thagann sé go dtín ár gcearta teanga nó aon chearta eile go bhfuilimid ina dteideal, nílimid ag stopadh go mbeidh siad againn agus bí cinnte go dtiocfaidh ár gcearta agus, leis sin, go dtiocfaidh ár lá.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - (The speaker intervenes in Catalan.)

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Mr President, this year marks 25 years since the adoption of the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages.I would like to draw attention to the systematic disregard for the European Charter by the Galician and Spanish authorities, as well as the need for the Galician government to revoke all the measures it has taken against the Galician language in recent years, including the decree onto teaching.These practices represent an intolerable contempt for our language and an attack on our linguistic rights on the part of those who have an obligation to protect them and provide the means to guarantee the full normalization of the Galician language and its uses in all areas.We also demand that the European Union and the Spanish Galician authorities respect and apply the European Charter and that Mr Tajani fully recognizes the Galician language and guarantees the Galician and Galician language rights in this Parliament.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: - (The speaker intervenes in Catalan.)

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, do you want Catalonia to be an independent state in the form of a republic? The Catalan people will be called by our government to answer that clear question by voting on 1 October. Despite further threats and pressures that may come from the Spanish authorities, we will make our choice, we will exercise our democratic right even if the Spanish state does not want us to, because, in a democracy, setting out ballot boxes and letting people vote can never be illegal. For a democracy to prevent a legitimate and widely demanded vote would be a dour, perverse undertaking that no democracy should accept. The people of Catalonia will vote because it is our right. This will be our opportunity to democratically take leave of a State with pervasive corruption, inefficient institutions, a politicised judiciary, and with a poor record in social justice and shared progress. Europe will then gain a new, modern republic.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, Theresa May has managed to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory. Consequently, there is much talk of a ‘soft Brexit’. There is no such thing as a hard or soft Brexit. There is only exit. ‘Soft Brexit’ is just code for not really leaving the EU at all. The Conservative and Labour manifestos were committed to implementing the result of the referendum but we cannot trust either party. Both are dominated by Remainers, who want to thwart Brexit if they can. Their best hope of doing that is by negotiating a deal whereby Britain leaves the EU in name, but not in substance. To avoid that, the British Parliament must immediately repeal the European Communities Act 1972, as the first step not the final step, in the process. We must leave the EU under our law, and then tell the EU how Brexit is going to work, not ask for permission on how we might leave.

name: Petr MACH
text: - When we joined the EU and Brussels ordered quotas on the number of cows, we were ridiculed.When we joined the European Union and import quotas became more expensive for bananas, we shrugged.When the EU introduced quotas for sugar production and we had to close our sugar factories, we were upset.When you introduced quotas for migrants, we began to worry about our own safety and the safety of our children.The European Commission is threatening our country today and wants fines, sanctions from us.That when we take subsidies, we have to take migrants as well.But we have our own rules on granting asylum, and our laws and our constitution take precedence over any decision by the European Union.You can threaten us with sanctions, you can take our subsidies, you can file lawsuits against us.But security is our number one priority and we will never exchange it for your euro.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I take the floor as the representative of Southern Italy, a land rich in agri-food excellence, to denounce how, among the hundred geographical indications that have been provided for in the agreement with China, there is only mozzarella buffalo from Campania as a product of Southern Italy. It seems very curious to me that the protection of German wine, which is a sophisticated wine, a sweetened wine, or Slovak wine, can be envisaged, and that the protection of Nero d'Avola or Bianco Alcamo is not envisaged, there is no provision for protection of extra virgin olive oil, the protection of the wonderful Sicilian oranges is not foreseen. Moreover, Southern Italy has been cut off from the Silk Road, speaking of China, and it seems that there is a plan that is aimed at destroying any type of production, any type of competitiveness, any type of dignity on the part of work and by products from that land. This is unacceptable and we need to understand what we need to do and where it goes like this.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Mr. President, on June 5, Egypt and several Arab countries accused Qatar of supporting terrorism. In the days that followed, several African states, including Senegal, severed diplomatic relations with Qatar. The charges against Qatar are very serious. They come from too many countries to be taken lightly. However, the European Union shines with its silence. It was Germany which intervened on its behalf, as too often, to explain that it is necessary, I quote: "to put an end to terrorism, within the framework of the anti-jihadist coalition of which Qatar is a part". We must stop the language of wood. Just a minute's silence in memory of the victims of the London bombing, as we did today in Strasbourg, is not enough. We must also and above all place Qatar in front of its responsibilities. Qatar has laughed at us for too long. He even went so far as to ask this Parliament to lift the immunity of a MEP whose only crime was to have criticized him. The time has come to react.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: That concludes the item. It was one rich in languages and maybe – in a rather narrower format – I could thank you all and thank the Commissioner for being with us until this late hour.
